The input network can be further developed to include a second PIN diode and an extended reactance network, providing a greater control range and selectivity of the input circuit compared to adjacent signal frequency bands.

• The invention is a system and method for spontaneously setting up a collaborative work-sharing environment between physically distant individuals.
• The system uses network-enabled applications to allow users to share information, conduct video conferences, etc., while maintaining their initial voice connection.
• The system uses a collaboration button and indicator on a telephone set to initiate the collaborative work-share environment.
• The system is designed to be easy to use, especially for users without technical background or training.
• The system can determine if the parties involved have the capability to collaborate and indicate this to the users.
• The system allows for the initiation of collaboration by either party, without interrupting the voice conversation.
• The system can be implemented in a variety of ways, including on top of dedicated telephone systems or using a peer-to-peer architecture.
• The system can be implemented as a computer program operating on a computer, and can be carried on a variety of storage or signal media.

* The invention describes a method and device for optimizing the visual impact of an advertising clip inserted into a video sequence. It takes into account the regions of interest of the video sequence and the advertising clip to ensure continuity between them.
* The method involves generating salience maps for the video sequence and each advertising clip, determining the degree of similarity between them, and selecting the advertising clip with the highest degree of similarity for insertion into the video sequence at a predefined insertion point, such as a shot change. The salience map can be generated from the last n pictures of the video sequence and the first p pictures of the advertising clip. The degree of similarity can be determined using various methods such as calculating the correlation coefficient or Kullback-Leibler divergence, or by selecting and calculating the Euclidean distance between the N most salient points of the salience maps.

• The invention relates to a recessed mask structure that prevents localized high electrical fields at intersections, reducing electrical breakdown in small dimension semiconductor devices and chip interconnect structures.
• The problem of high electrical fields is due to small dimensional tolerances and the use of different materials with different properties, such as lower dielectric constant (k), in the sub 250 nanometer range.
• The invention provides a metal plus low dielectric constant (low-k) interconnect structure, where a differentiating or mask member is positioned below the surface to be planarized, reducing lateral leakage current and lowering the effective dielectric constant.
• The invention is particularly useful in damascene type device structures, where masking is employed to protect the dielectric material between conductors during processing operations and to assist in patterning those trenches within the interlevel dielectric material.
• The recessed mask structure leads to a lower and predictable overall capacitance, resulting in faster signal propagation in the interconnect wiring.
• The invention can be implemented using a standard substrate, bulk layer of intralevel dielectric material, via and trench openings, conductive diffusion barrier liners, and copper electroplating. The surface is then chemically-mechanically polished, and the intralevel dielectric material is gently etched to establish the dimension.

- The Downconverting Digitizer of this invention is a novel design implementation for an analog to digital converter that samples and downconverts a modulated (IF) carrier to baseband in-phase (I) and quadrature (Q) components. It consists of a digitally-controlled variable gain amplifier, a gain control logic element, an analog summing element, a sampling element, a predictive digital filter, an offset nuller element, a digital summing element, a digital to analog converter, a digital quadrature mixer, and two rate reduction filters.
- The Downconverting Digitizer operates on the principle of the predictive loop, which generates a prediction of the input signal. When the prediction is subtracted from the input signal, a prediction error signal is generated. In the steady-state mode of operation, this predictive loop minimizes the prediction error signal. The sampler plays a critical role in the operation of the Downconverting Digitizer by converting the analog error signal into a digital representation.
- The predictive filter is implemented using digital signal processing techniques and is designed to generate a prediction of the modulated IF at the next sampling epoch. The poles of the predictive filter are placed to coincide in the frequency domain with the center frequency of the alias component of the modulated IF after being sampled by the sampler.
- The predictive filter element is implemented as a cascade of filter stages, each of which is implemented as a second-order filter. The complex pole pair of each stage is located in the z-plane as shown in FIG. 4. Adjusting the filter coefficient varies the angle between the positive real axis and the radius to the pole, determining the resonant frequency of the filter stage, and varies the radial distance of the pole pair relative to the origin of the z-plane, determining the 3-dB bandwidth of the filter stage.

<summary>

* The text describes a method for fabricating arrays of nano-scale features on a single wafer to form a sensor device or a matrix of devices for multiplex detection of selected analytes using many simultaneous detection zones, by detecting changes in electrical characteristics of the nano-scale materials for each device.
* The method uses nanoimprint lithography to define groups of semiconducting nanotraces between electrodes, which can be used as a sensor or, when anchored probe molecules are covalently coupled or synthesized to the surfaces, be used for multiplex detection of analytes.
* Nanoimprint lithography also provides a method to fabricate arrays of semiconducting electrode "nanotraces" in a controllable and regular pattern in a single processing step.
* A method that provides controlled fabrication of nanophase features provides a means for detection of gases adsorbed on the semiconductor surfaces or multiplex detection of many simultaneous detection zones.
* Binding of complementary targets to the anchored probe molecules in the vicinity of the semiconducting active layer produces a change in electrical conductivity of the semiconducting active layer that can be monitored externally for each sensor device in the array in parallel.
* The method includes the fabrication of a set of parallel nanotraces that serve to homogenize the total response to changes in local environment since the total response is the average of the response of each nanotrace connected in parallel between the interdigitated finger region of the source and drain electrodes.
* Averaging the response over a number of nanotraces lowers the failure rate of sensor devices during fabrication of the multiplex detection array.
* The method also includes the use of photogenerated reagents (PGR) for massively parallel synthesis of DNA, RNA, and PNA molecules, and the use of nanoimprint lithography (NIL) for patterning nano-scale features into a quartz plate, which can be applied directly to the surface of a wafer and transferring the pattern 1:1 into a photoresist layer.
</summary>

* The present invention describes a method of singulating and plating semiconductor packages to prevent contamination of lead surfaces.
* The method involves plating the side surfaces of the leads of the leadframe with a plating material that is a different material than the leads.
* The leads are copper and the plating material can be tin, silver, gold, nickel-gold, nickel-palladium, or nickel-palladium-gold.
* The singulation process can be performed in one full cutting operation or in multiple partial cutting operations.
* The plating process can be performed before or after the singulation process.
* The molding compound can have a top surface, bottom surface, and side surfaces that can have a step, beveled portion, or non-beveled portion.

* The text describes a method and system for a mobile terminal to switch between a wireless wide area network (WWAN) and a wireless local area network (WLAN) in a communication system.
* The WLAN gathers service information of neighboring base stations from an access point and transmits it to the mobile terminal. This information allows the mobile terminal to skip some of the connection setup time when switching to the WWAN.
* The mobile terminal contains a first network module (e.g. GSM module) for connecting to the WWAN and a second network module (e.g. WiFi module) for connecting to the WLAN and receiving service information.
* The system uses a set of rules to determine when to switch between the WWAN and WLAN, and the mobile terminal uses the service information to select a serving base station when switching to the WWAN.

• The text describes a new process for manufacturing multilayered components, specifically multilayer capacitors, which simplifies the manufacturing process and reduces cost.
• The process involves providing a first electrode and a first electrical component and locating the electrode in a recess formed by the component to produce a first laminate sub-assembly, and repeating this process to produce a second laminate sub-assembly. These sub-assemblies are then stacked to form a resultant assembly.
• The process eliminates the need for certain steps in traditional manufacturing methods, such as cutting and metallizing, and allows for the use of multiple first electrodes and first components on a first decal, and multiple second electrodes and second components on a second decal.
• The process also allows for the interconnection of electrodes in stacked sub-assemblies, precise registered relation of sub-assemblies, and the use of covering components at upper and lower ends of the stacks.
• The resultant sub-assemblies and assemblies can be used to form capacitors, coils, resistances, or combinations thereof.
• The process can also be adapted to other electronic ceramic devices such as multilayer ferrite inductors, multilayer substrates, semiconductor packages, and precision registers.

• The text describes a hierarchical lattice structure with unit cells of various sizes connected together to form a lightweight lattice structure with improved specific stiffness and strength.
• The unit cells can have different geometric structures, such as tetrahedral, pyramidal, octet truss, or three-dimensional Kagome.
• The lattice structure can be made by joining ligaments of adjacent cells together at nodes, or by attaching ligaments of their respective cells after construction.
• The lattice structure can be nested with an ancillary array of unit cells to form a lattice structure with improved properties.
• The lattice structure can be mated with an oppositely oriented lattice structure to form a mated lattice structure with improved stability and strength.
• The lattice structure can be used as the core of a sandwich panel or other structure, and can be implemented with or as part of floors, columns, beams, walls, jet or rocket nozzles, land, air or water vehicles/ships, armor, etc.
• The lattice structures and arrays can be fabricated from thermoformable materials through the use of an injection molding process.
• The lattice structure can be used as a template for the deposition of other materials, such as silicon carbide, to form a solid coating over the lattice structure.
• The lattice structure can be used in various applications, such as impact or blast energy absorption, catalyst support, thin film battery deposition, and heat exchange.
• The lattice structure can be manufactured in other ways including lattice block construction, constructed metal lattice, and metal textile lay-up techniques.

- The invention describes a process for co-producing power and hydrocarbons using an Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle (IGCC) process and a hydrocarbon production process. Coal is gasified in a wet gasification stage to produce a combustion gas at elevated pressure, which is then used to generate power and enrich a first portion of the combustion gas with hydrogen. The enriched gas is then mixed with a synthesis gas precursor produced in a dry gasification stage to produce a synthesis gas for hydrocarbon synthesis.
- The process aims to show economic and environmental benefits by integrating the IGCC process with a hydrocarbon production process. The wet gasification stage uses water as a carrier for solid feedstock, while the dry gasification stage uses a gas as a carrier. The molar ratio of H2 and CO in the combustion gas is higher than that in the synthesis gas precursor, and the dry gasification stage produces synthesis gas at a sufficiently high pressure for hydrocarbon synthesis. The process also includes purifying a portion of the H2-enriched gas to produce essentially pure hydrogen for hydroprocessing of hydrocarbons.

• The present invention relates to a method for preparing a solid device for use as an oxide superconducting material, which improves the properties of the material at the surface or portion close to the surface.
• The method involves forming a blocking film (passivation film) on the surface of the superconducting material using an photo CVD method, and adding oxygen onto the surface or portion close to the surface, followed by heat treatment to position the added oxygen in the appropriate atom location.
• The blocking film prevents the removal of oxygen from the surface, and the added oxygen increases the density of the insulating material, providing a more complete blocking layer.
• The method can be used with various superconducting materials, including those formed into tablets or thin films, and can be used to create a Josephson element structure or a passivation film.
• The invention aims to provide a highly reliable surface utilizing-device by maintaining the oxygen concentration of the surface in an ideal status when maintained at the temperature of liquid nitrogen.

<summary>
  * The invention describes an apparatus for preparing foam sheet samples for microscopic examination, with a focus on creating precise, laboratory-quality cross-sectional specimens.
  * The apparatus includes a base plate, support columns, a top deck plate, a support bar, a clamp bar, and a cutting mechanism. The clamp bar can be adjusted to hold foam sheet samples in place, and the cutting mechanism can make repetitive, parallel cuts for microscopic examination.
</summary>

The apparatus is designed to handle delicate foam sheet samples, which can be difficult to cut without damaging their cell structure. By using a razor blade and a screw thread specimen advance mechanism, the apparatus can create uniform, parallel cuts that expose the cross-sectional structure of the foam sheet. This is important for quality control purposes, as it allows for detailed examination of the individual cells within the sheet.

The apparatus is particularly useful for foam sheet stock used in the manufacture of containers such as coffee and soft drink cups, which has an overall thickness in the range of 0.015 inch to 0.040 inch and a density of 10-15 pounds per cubic foot. The invention also notes that the apparatus can be used to establish performance criteria for different foam materials, as well as to preserve the structure of individual cells within the sample for microscopic examination.

• The invention is related to seismometers, specifically those designed for underwater use, and aims to determine the angle of inclination and level seismic motion detectors.
• Seismometers are crucial for geological research, and underwater seismometers (OBS) are used in deep-water oil and natural gas exploration.
• OBS are placed on the ocean floor with minimal user control, often resulting in poor seismic coupling. The invention helps determine the angle of inclination to assess ocean floor contour and evaluate data quality.
• The invention includes a method and apparatus for leveling seismic motion detectors, which typically have a preferred operating axis (vertical or horizontal) and sense motion along a parallel axis.
• Leveling is achieved using gimbals, a boat floating in liquid, or the invention's novel device, which is simpler and more cost-effective.
• The invention also describes an electronic system for timing various functions and a release mechanism for on-bottom seismometers.
• The invention involves suspending a seismic motion detector at the end of a shaft connected to a ball in an annular seat, forming a free-moving pendulum.
• A spring-loaded plunger locks the ball, shaft, and detector in place when the seismometer is deployed, ensuring good acoustic coupling between the ocean bottom and the detector.
• The invention's objectives include providing a simple and inexpensive method to determine the angle of inclination, preserving the orientation for later measurement, ensuring good acoustic coupling, and self-leveling seismic motion detectors.

1. The humidity sensing element of the present invention is a small, hollow cylinder made of commercially pure aluminum with a bore that has been anodized and impregnated with nickel particles. The anodized layer is sealed and overlaid with a porous vacuum deposition of nickel to form a second electrode. This sensing element is suitable for excitation by a ten Hertz sine wave alternating current electrical voltage and is used in a solid state electronic measurement circuit to measure relative humidity.
2. The manufacturing process for the sensing element includes anodizing the aluminum bore, depositing nickel particles in the anodized layer using vacuum deposition, sealing the anodized layer, and vacuum depositing a thin, water vapor pervious electrode over the nickel-impregnated sealed anodized layer. This process results in a sensor with a doped dielectric layer formed by the nickel impregnated sealed portion of the anodized layer, which is vapor pervious and electrically conductive.
3. The sensor functions by combining capacitance and resistance in a suitable manner such that its total impedance varies essentially linearly proportionally with the relative humidity. The impedance of the sensor changes almost instantly in response to relative humidity changes due to the thin and molecularly porous dielectric and second electrode. The sensor is self-contained and forms its own protection for the humidity-sensitive portion in its bore, while the surrounding atmosphere may circulate freely through the bore for free exchange of atmospheric molecules with the dielectric layer.

* The text describes a motor assembly with a force transmission structure for a window lift system in a vehicle.
* The force transmission structure includes a drive plate and a shaft, with the shaft having a toothed portion that fits into the drive plate's mounting hole.
* The drive plate has a Y-shaped mounting hole and the shaft has a Y-shaped toothed portion, allowing for stable rotation and quiet movement of the window lift system.
* The contact area between the teeth of the shaft and the coupling of the drive plate is greater than in traditional designs, allowing for greater torque resistance.
* The drive plate is made of an engineering plastics material, which has good strength, resistance to impact, and can absorb vibration to reduce noise.
* Buffer holes in the drive plate aid in molding and reduce distortion of the mounting hole.
* The motor assembly includes a motor, a gear train, and a capstan, which is a part of a window lift mechanism.
* The gear train comprises a worm, a worm gear, a damper, the drive plate, and the shaft.
* The worm gear teeth mesh with the worm, and the damper is made of rubber material and has first and second slots for fittingly receiving the ribs of the worm gear and the protrusions of the drive plate, respectively.

• The text describes a system and method for generating a mobile time reference for a portable transceiver in a wireless communication system. The system includes an antenna, a radio frequency subsystem with a high frequency oscillator and a low frequency oscillator, and a baseband subsystem with a free running counter. The free running counter provides a mobile time reference to the system and has a wake mode and a sleep mode. During the wake mode, the free running counter uses the high frequency oscillator to generate the mobile time reference, and during the sleep mode, the free running counter uses the low frequency oscillator to maintain the mobile time reference.
• The mobile time reference is used for detecting, identifying, and monitoring multipath signals, which are two or more identical signals from the same antenna reaching the receiver at different times due to taking different paths from the antenna to the receiver. The system and method are particularly useful in 3G wireless communication systems, which aim to raise transmission speeds and add mobile capabilities to services such as Internet and intranet access, videoconferencing, and interactive application sharing.
• The system and method are also used for maintaining the mobile time reference during idle mode, which allows the portable transmitter to quickly transition to an active state and reduces power consumption and extends battery life. The mobile time reference is maintained to a 32 nanosecond accuracy, which improves the efficiency of detecting, identifying, and monitoring incoming multipath signals.

<summary>
  * The invention describes a helmet liner that can be custom-fitted to an individual's head.
  * The liner is made up of multiple layers of elastic thermoplastic sheets with an array of pockets.
  * The liner is fitted to the wearer's head by heating the sheets to a plastic state, placing the liner on the head, and allowing it to cool and harden.
  * The open and unfilled pockets in the liner allow for deformation and conformity to the contours of the wearer's head.
  * The liner can be refitted to accommodate a changed head size by reheating and repeating the fitting process.
  * The liner is simple and inexpensive to manufacture and does not require trimming or drawstrings.
  * The invention provides a helmet liner with uniform structural characteristics, predictable performance, and resistance to shifting position on the wearer's head.
  </summary>

• The invention is a multiorifice wafer structure having a plurality of angularly disposed passages and a method for making the multiorifice structure. The structure is made by fusing concentric layers of solid rods interspaced with cylindrically shaped members, with each successive layer of rods disposed at a progressively larger angle with respect to the axis of the fused assembly. The fused assembly is then cut into thin wafers, and the interstices formed between the fused layers of rods and the cylindrical members form a plurality of angularly disposed passageways.
• The structure comprises a plurality of layers of rods separated by cylindrical members. The interstices between the individual rods and the cylindrical members form a plurality of generally triangularly shaped passageways through the structure, which constitute the orifices through which the fluid to be dispersed or atomized flows. The thickness of the structure is selected such that the fluid passing therethrough will, upon exiting the structure, have a directional component parallel to the axis of the interstices.
• A simple and economical method for fabricating the disclosed multiorifice structure is illustrated, which comprises circumscribing a core rod by a plurality of rods or wires, twisting the rods about the core at a predetermined angle, and sheathing the twisted rods in a cylindrical member. A second layer of rods is twisted about the external surface of the cylindrical member and sheathed in a second cylindrical member, with the twisted rods on the second layer angularly disposed with regard to the core rod at a different angle. The process is repeated until the composite structure has the desired diameter, which is then fused or sintered to form an integral structure.

• The text describes a method of manufacturing a semiconductor device with an LDD (Lightly Doped Drain) structure, which aims to improve the controllability of the width of the oxide portion on the gate sidewall, enable the formation of an LDD structure by a low-temperature process, and prevent degradation of the transconductance and increase of resistances due to hot-carrier injection into the oxide portion on the gate sidewall.
• The method involves forming an insulating film on the gate electrode, substrate, and sidewall, then forming a layer on the insulating film and anisotropically etching it away using RIE, leaving a portion on the gate sidewall. This conformal layer can be made of polycrystalline silicon, oxide, high melting point metal, or silicides. The low density region of the source/drain region is formed by ion injection of an impurity using the oxide film of the gate and the insulating film on the gate as a mask. A conductive layer or polycrystalline semiconductor layer is formed after the insulating film on the gate electrode, which is then anisotropically etched away using RIE to form the portion on the gate sidewall. The method also features siliciding a desired portion of the gate electrode or the gate electrode and the source/drain region in fabricating the insulated gate field effect semiconductor device having the LDD structure.

• The text describes an improved IP (Internet-protocol) telephone system that can be used as a conventional wireless telephone or an IP telephone.
• The system includes an enhanced wireless telephone with a speech coder and decoder, a digital interface, an antenna, a radio frequency transceiver, and an external connection.
• The external connection can be coupled to a PC and a network interface, allowing coded speech signals to be formatted by a software telephony application and transmitted to a network.
• The system can operate in two modes: wireless-telephone mode, in which the digital interface directs output to the radio frequency transceiver for wireless communication, and IP-telephone mode, in which the digital interface directs output to the external connection for IP communication.
• The speech coder and decoder use the same algorithms as during radio-telephone operation, and are constructed to operate at high speed using relatively little power.
• The system provides several advantages over conventional IP telephones, including reduced burden on the telephony application and CPU, elimination of the need for a sound card, microphone, or speaker in the PC, and a convenient and comfortable handset for the user.

* The invention is about devices for producing electrical power, pressurized water or other useful work from surface waves on a water body.
* The devices rely on subsurface differences in hydrostatic pressure and/or enhanced surge or pitch which expand and contract or otherwise deform or deflect one or more gas filled submerged containers, producing useful work.
* Wave energy commercialization lags behind wind energy due to high cost per average unit of energy capture caused by heavy steel construction and low wave energy capture efficiency.
* Hundreds of unique OWECs have been proposed, but only a dozen are currently deployed as commercial prototypes, all suffering from high cost per average unit of energy capture.
* Most subsurface OWECs are designed for near shore sea bed deployment, but ocean waves lose substantial energy as they approach shore due to breaking or reflected wave and bottom and hydrodynamic friction effects.
* Near shore submerged sea bed OWECs must be deployed at greater depths relative to average wave trough depths due to severe sea-state considerations to avoid breaking wave turbulence, and depth can not be adjusted for the large tidal depth variations found at higher latitudes.
* Wave induced subsurface static pressure oscillations diminish more rapidly in shallow water as the depth below waves or swell troughs increases.
* Only a few prior art subsurface devices use gas filled or evacuated containers like the present invention, producing container deformation in response to overhead swell and trough induced static pressure changes.
* None of the prior art subsurface OWECs capture both hydrostatic (heave) and hydrokinetic wave energy (surge or pitch) which represents half of all wave energy.
* None of these prior art subsurface OWECs enhance or supplement energy capture with overhead floating bodies.

* The text describes a blade for a scraped surface heat exchanger, which is used in industry for processing foodstuffs.
* The blade is hingedly connected to a central drive shaft in the heat exchanger and has a scraping edge to prevent material buildup.
* The blade is mounted to the drive shaft using pins, which have a narrow protruding finger and a wider finger.
* The blade is inserted at an installation angle, and then pivoted to a more shallow angle, at which point the inner finger of the pin protrudes through a hole in the blade, restraining it from lateral movement.
* The invention aims to facilitate the mounting of the blade onto the drive shaft while still using a pin type connection.
* The blade includes L-shaped locking tracks on both sides, which interfere with the pin and lock the blade against longitudinal movement while permitting pivoting movement.
* The locking tracks are made roughly half as thick as would be required for a single track on one side of the blade, reducing wear and tear.
* The invention includes several figures that illustrate the blade, pin, and their assembly during the installation process.

* The invention describes a process and apparatus for detecting and eliminating defective or incorrectly positioned cigarettes in a cigarette magazine of a cigarette production and/or packaging machine.
* The detection process uses an optical checking element, such as a camera, to scan and evaluate images of cigarettes in the magazine. If the scanned image deviates from a reference image or reference value, an error signal is produced.
* The detection apparatus includes an optical checking element, an image-processing device, and means to produce an error signal. The optical checking element scans images of cigarettes in the magazine, which are then evaluated by the image-processing device. If a deviation is detected, an error signal is produced.
* The elimination process involves detecting a defective or incorrectly positioned cigarette and actuating an ejecting unit to remove a plurality of cigarettes located in an ejecting zone assigned to the ejecting unit.
* The elimination apparatus includes at least one ejecting unit arranged in the region of the magazine, which is intended for ejecting a plurality of cigarettes located in an ejecting zone assigned to the ejecting unit.
* The invention aims to improve the avoidance of disruptions in the cigarette magazine and reduce the laborious and costly steps involved in eliminating disruptions.

* The invention describes a device for interconnecting high voltage cables with an apparatus or a second high voltage cable, consisting of a cable termination and a rigid insulator. The aim is to simplify the connection system for high voltage cables up to 400 KV and above, providing a common cable connection system for all accessories and interconnections.
* The invention includes three interface methods: an inner cone concept, an outer cone concept, and a no cone or slight inner cone concept. The outer cone concept separates the cable connection further from the apparatus it is connected to, making it less likely for a fault at one side to affect the other side. The inner cone concept allows for a shorter solution outside an SF6 cubicle, but may face problems with coned surfaces made by different suppliers.
* The invention also describes various applications of the outer cone concept, including SF6 terminals, transformer terminals, out-door terminals, straight through joints, transition joints, and joints between two apparatus. The rigid insulator used in these applications should have a conical interface surface with an angle between 15° and 45°.

<summary>
  * The invention describes a fixing mechanism for a tool used in machining materials such as wood, plastics, and metal. The mechanism includes a tool, a frame, and a tool holder in the frame of a machine tool.
  * The fixing mechanism can be used in various applications including machining by chipping, cutting, punching, molding, and forming work, particularly in machining of metal sheets in sheet machining centers.
  * The mechanism uses a curved surface for fixing the tool, which provides a simple and secure way of placing the tool in the tool holder and transmitting machining force.
  * The text also describes various embodiments of the invention with different configurations of the tool, tool frame, and tool holder.
  </summary>

The text describes a fixing mechanism for a tool used in a wide range of technology including machining by chipping, such as milling, reaming, drilling, turning, etc. of wood, plastics, metal, etc. The fixing mechanism can be used in various types of robot applications for production, in the exchange of grippers or the like in other automatic devices, such as apparatus for transfer and treatment of pieces, in pneumatic tools, etc., wherein exchange of tools required for different kinds of operations is necessary for carrying out various operations. The fixing mechanism is particularly advantageous for use in cutting, punching, moulding and forming work, particularly in machining of metal sheets in so-called sheet machining centers. The tool-fixing mechanism according to the invention can be used for fixing both the actual machining tool and its counterpart, i.e. the so-called cushion, to the tool holder in the frame of the machine tool.

The text also describes the background of the invention, which is the use of a conic fit, i.e. a Morse conic fit, for fixing a tool, whereby the tool frame and the tool holder are joined to each other by a fixing movement in their axial direction, the release being effected in a corresponding manner in the axial direction. However, this method has the disadvantage that the connecting surfaces very easily tend to be clamped too much against each other, particularly under effect of axial forces. Many systems presently in use comprise special release mechanisms for releasing clamped conic surfaces in connection with the exchange of a tool. As a natural result,

• The text describes a continuation of a patent application related to switching circuitry for display drivers that operates at high speeds and produces low electromagnetic interference (EMI).
• Two common techniques for generating supply voltages to display driver circuits are charge pump circuits and switching regulator circuits. Charge pump circuits have high energy efficiency but low current driving capability, while switching regulator circuits have lower power conversion efficiency but can supply higher current.
• The invention provides methods and apparatus for generating supply voltages for display driver circuits at very high efficiencies and low quantities of radiated energy (i.e., low noise) by modifying switching regulator circuits to create multiple circuit paths that carry electric current in opposite directions to cancel out the radiated noise.
• In one embodiment, parallel source and drain paths are configured in an alternating relationship to cancel out EMI generated in the source paths by the EMI generated in the drain paths.
• In another embodiment, terminal leads are used at the periphery edges of the circuit to act as RF antennas to pick up any leaking fields generated by the last fully-connected paths in the circuit.
• The invention enables the production of relatively large amounts of current for driver circuits for relatively large displays, such as the Apple iPhone display, without incurring the typical penalties associated with EMI or noise.
• The reduction in EMI can be increased through the use of terminal leads, and media player apparatus operating in accordance with the methods and circuits of the present invention are also provided.

• Vehicle battery rebalancing is a process that corrects cell voltage imbalance conditions by measuring the voltage of each cell, identifying the cell with the minimum voltage, and bleeding down the other cells until their voltages are approximately equal. This process is necessary for maintaining the health and longevity of the battery.
• A power system may include a battery with multiple cells and a controller that causes the cells to acquire charge at different rates for a certain period of time, such that the voltages of the cells become approximately equal at the end of that period. This technique can potentially reduce the time required to rebalance and charge the battery.
• The time required to rebalance and charge a battery can be significant, with up to 50% or more dedicated to rebalancing. Certain embodiments provide systems and techniques that aim to minimize this time, which can be beneficial for plug-in hybrid electric vehicle (PHEV) or battery electric vehicle (BEV) owners.

• The text describes an AC-to-DC converter used as a lamp power supply that converts an AC input voltage to a constant DC voltage, reducing eye fatigue and protecting eyesight and health by eliminating low and high frequency flicker and electromagnetic radiation.
• The converter includes various circuits such as an input protection circuit, EMI filter, rectifier, filter, converter, output filter, lamp, start circuit, control circuit, biasing circuit, sampling circuit, output protection circuit, feedback and dimming circuit, and input monitor circuit.
• The converter can be implemented using different topologies such as Flyback, Buck, Boost, Buck-boost, H-Bridge, Forward, and Two-transistor Flyback, and can be used in various applications such as bus AC to DC converter, PFC converter, computer power supply, TV power supply, and electronic ballast.

1. The text describes a system and method for maintaining a desired illumination profile in a space using both daylight and artificial light. The system includes sensors for sensing illumination levels, electrically controllable window treatments for controlling the amount of daylight entering the space, and a control system that adjusts the window treatments and dimming levels of electric lamps to maintain the desired illumination profile. The control system can also adjust the window treatments to reduce sun glare.
2. The system can be controlled using either open loop or closed loop control algorithms. In open loop control, the system uses signals from interior light sensors that predominantly sense daylight entering the space. In closed loop control, the system uses signals from interior light sensors that predominantly sense a combination of daylight entering the space and light generated by the electric light sources being controlled.
3. The system can use a single photosensor or a single averaged reading from a plurality of interior sensors as an input for a closed loop algorithm for control of window treatments and an open loop algorithm for control of electric lights. This eliminates the need for exterior sensors and complex data gathering and setup procedures, reducing the overall system cost. The system can also automatically recalibrate based on immediate or repeated occupant input, increasing occupant satisfaction.

<summary>

* The text describes the state of aviation security in the United States before and after the September 11 attacks in 2001.
* It highlights vulnerabilities in aviation security, including weaknesses in passenger and baggage screening, access controls at airports, and the security of air traffic control computer systems.
* The text also discusses the establishment of the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) and the implementation of the Aviation and Transportation Security Act (ATSA) to address these vulnerabilities.
* It notes that while progress has been made in improving aviation security, challenges remain, including the need for a risk management approach, adequate funding, coordination, strategic human capital management, and building a results-oriented organization.
</summary>

• The Lobbying Disclosure Act (LDA) of 1995 and the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) sections 4911 and 162(e) have different definitions of lobbying activities and covered officials.
• LDA covers only federal lobbying, while IRC sections 4911 and 162(e) cover both federal and state lobbying. IRC sections 4911 and 162(e) also cover grassroots lobbying, which is not covered by LDA.
• The definitions of covered officials and lobbying activities under LDA, IRC section 4911, and IRC section 162(e) can significantly affect who must register and what they must report under LDA, as well as the expenses reported under each definition.

• GAO has been assessing strategic sourcing in federal acquisitions for over a decade.
• Strategic sourcing involves a shift from individual procurements to an enterprise-wide approach, leading to leveraged buying power and substantial savings.
• Tactics include leveraged buying, managing demand, standardization, total cost of ownership evaluation, and supplier relationship management.
• Comprehensive spend analysis is crucial for efficient procurement, providing insights into spending patterns, buyers, suppliers, and opportunities for savings.
• Federal departments and agencies have not fully leveraged their buying power due to decentralized procurement and reliance on numerous separate contracts.
• OMB implemented strategic sourcing practices in 2005, directing agencies to develop and implement strategic sourcing efforts based on spend analyses.
• The Federal Strategic Sourcing Initiative (FSSI) was established in 2005 to address government-wide opportunities for strategic sourcing and eliminate duplication of efforts.
• In 2011, the DOD, DHS, DOE, and VA accounted for 80% of federal procurement spending, but only managed about 5% of that spending through strategic sourcing efforts.
• Realizing cost savings and benefits from strategic sourcing depends on utilization of these contracts, but only 15% of government-wide spending for covered products and services went through FSSI contracts in 2011.
• Challenges to strategic sourcing in the federal setting include data issues, lack of expertise, leadership support, and clear guidance on metrics for measuring success.

• Current federal surface transportation programs are not effective at addressing key challenges, such as increasing congestion and growing freight demand, due to unclear goals and lack of links to needs or performance. Many programs lack rigorous economic analysis for project selection and have insufficient mechanisms to link programs to goals.

• The Highway Trust Fund, which funds most surface transportation programs, is facing fiscal sustainability issues as expenditures now exceed revenues, and the balance is projected to be exhausted soon. The federal role in transportation funding must be reexamined to ensure sustainability in the context of broader fiscal imbalance.

• The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is responsible for aviation safety oversight, air traffic control (ATC), and airport infrastructure development.
• The costs associated with FAA's activities are primarily driven by the volume and nature of the services provided, with safety activities being the largest cost driver.
• FAA's safety activities include licensing pilots and mechanics, as well as inspecting various aspects of the aviation system.
• ATC includes a variety of complex activities that guide and control the flow of aircraft through the National Airspace System (NAS), with costs being influenced by the amount and nature of services used by each flight.
• FAA funds airport infrastructure development through the Airport Improvement Program (AIP), a multibillion-dollar grant program that provides funding for airports included in FAA’s National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems.
• The Trust Fund was established to help fund the development of a nationwide airport and airway system, and is credited with revenues collected from system users through dedicated excise taxes on airline tickets, cargo/mail, fuel, and international arrivals/departures.
• The National Civil Aviation Review Commission identified concerns with FAA’s funding structure, including the disconnect between revenues contributed by users and the costs they impose on the NAS, and recommended that FAA’s revenues be more closely linked to the costs of services provided.
• Alternative funding options for FAA include relying solely on a fuel tax, increasing the passenger segment tax, weight/distance charges, en-route charges, flight segment charges, and certification charges. However, any assessment of the current or alternative funding options is only preliminary without more detailed information and an understanding of the costs different flights impose on the NAS.

1. * The Institute of Medicine published a report in 1993 that discussed secret U.S. chemical weapons programs during World War II, which found that an estimated 60,000 military personnel participated as human experimental subjects in tests of exposure to mustard agents and lewisite.
2. * In response to this report, the Deputy Secretary of Defense issued an agencywide memo that released individuals from nondisclosure restrictions, tasked the secretaries of the military departments to declassify and provide information about individuals who were potentially exposed, and directed the Office of the Under Secretary of Defense for Personnel and Readiness (OUSD (P&R)) to establish a task force to monitor the status of DOD’s efforts.
3. * OUSD (P&R), the military services, and VA developed the Chemical Weapons Exposure Study Task Force to identify DOD personnel exposed to chemical substances during testing, training, transport, production, and storage. The task force identified approximately 6,400 servicemembers and civilians who were potentially exposed to mustard, lewisite, and other chemical substances.
4. * The Defense Authorization Act for FY 2003 required DOD to submit to Congress and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs a comprehensive plan for the review, declassification, and submittal to VA of all DOD records and information on Project 112 that are relevant to the provision of benefits by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to members of the armed forces who participated in that project. DOD identified 5,842 servicemembers and estimated that 350 civilians had been potentially exposed during Project 112 tests, and this information was entered into a Project 112 database.
