2. To reduce parasitic signals, the drive signal was set to half the actuation frequency, causing the amplitude of motion of the resonator to be proportional to the square of the actuation voltage.
3. A bias voltage was used to down-mix the resistance change of the gauges, and the low-frequency readout signal was detected using a lock-in amplifier.
4. Measurements were taken in a vacuum chamber at a pressure of 10 mbar and at room temperature, with thermomechanical noise measured using the same setup with the drive electrode disconnected.
5. The allan deviation was measured in open-loop configuration and the frequency stability was extracted from the response of the resonator actuated at resonance frequency with a fixed driving frequency.
6. The phase of the measured signal was monitored and transformed into frequency fluctuations using the phase response of the resonator.
7. Correlation measurements were performed by simultaneously measuring the response of the resonator at different frequencies within the resonator's bandwidth.
8. The phase traces were converted to frequency traces corresponding to different integration times, and the correlation of these frequency traces was calculated and plotted versus the integration time. The correlation was processed so that it only depends on frequency variations with characteristic time close to the integration time.

• Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of death in the United States, accounting for 29.4% of total deaths in 2010 and costing over $312.6 billion in healthcare spending and lost productivity.
• Aspirin therapy can reduce the risk of major CVD events, and is recommended for primary and secondary prevention of CVD by the US Preventive Services Task Force and the American Heart Association.
• A study analyzing the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) for the years 2011-2012 found that among adults aged 40 and older, only 31.5% reported being recommended by their doctor to take aspirin for primary prevention of CVD.
• The study also found that education level, insurance status, and having a regular source of care were predictive of receiving a recommendation for aspirin for CVD prevention among all primary prevention patients.
• Among high-risk individuals, age, health insurance, and being of Asian/other descent were predictive of receiving a recommendation for aspirin for CVD prevention.
• The study suggests that decisions for treatment recommendations seem to be being made on criteria other than objectively calculated future CVD risk, and that there is a need for improved clinical decision support to aid in making accurate decisions.

1. Mitochondria produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) during oxidative metabolism, which can regulate signaling by oxidizing protein cysteine residues and forming disulfide or sulfenyl amide bonds.
2. Oxidative events required for the effects of ROS on cellular signaling pathways are not well understood, but increased mitochondrial and oxidant content appears to correlate with stem cell differentiation.
3. In the epidermis, a self-renewing stratified squamous epithelium, mitochondrial metabolism and ROS production promote signaling through pathways required for differentiation of mammalian stem cell populations.
4. Conditionally deleting TFAM, a transcription factor required for mitochondrial genome replication and transcription, in basal undifferentiated epidermal keratinocytes results in impaired differentiation and an epidermal barrier defect.
5. MROS generation is required for activation of the Notch and β-catenin transcriptional programs that promote epidermal differentiation and hair growth, respectively.
6. Nucleoredoxin (NXN) has been identified as a putative target of MROS-mediated Wnt/β-catenin signaling, and becomes oxidized in response to Wnt-3a treatment in wild-type keratinocytes.
7. Mitochondrial calcium uptake promotes keratinocyte differentiation in vitro, and uncoupling protein 2 (UCP2) may act as a metabolic switch that controls stem cell differentiation.
8. Mitochondrial metabolism promotes cellular differentiation by providing substrates for histone acetyltransferases and demethylases, and histone methylation status is regulated by histone methyltransferases and demethylases with various methylation codes associated with transcriptional activation or repression.

1. Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is a single-stranded RNA virus that belongs to the Flaviviridae family. Its study has mainly progressed in the field of functional analysis and therapeutic implications.
2. The diagnosis of HCV infection is made with a branched chain DNA signal amplification assay and reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR).
3. A new in situ hybridization (ISH) technique using a locked nucleic acid (LNA) probe and biotin-free tyramide amplification system (CSALII) was established to detect HCV-RNA in formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) tissue sections of the liver.
4. The new ISH technique was tested on humanized liver specimens from HCV-infected chimeric mice and needle biopsy liver specimens of chronic hepatitis C.
5. The new ISH technique was able to detect HCV-RNA in infected hepatocytes in FFPE sections, and the LNA-modified oligonucleotide probe used is one of the most sensitive probes for ISH.
6. The new ISH technique can be applied to detecting HCV-RNA in liver biopsy specimens, and it is relatively simple and requires no special equipment to perform. It seems to be suitable for demonstrating HCV genome in FFPE sections and will become a valuable tool for routine histopathological diagnosis of HCV infection using FFPE liver biopsy specimens.

* Endocrine-disrupting chemicals can have significant effects on wild animals and humans.
  * Many chemicals have been shown to alter the thyroid system in vertebrates, making the thyroid axis an important consideration for chemical regulation.
  * The OECD and EPA have established guidelines for investigating frog metamorphosis as a way to study thyroid toxicity.
  * Frog tadpoles are particularly susceptible to contaminants in wastewater due to their thin, permeable skin and aquatic environment.
  * The dramatic structural and functional changes of larval tissues during metamorphosis can be used as parameters for reflecting endocrine disruption.
  * Thyroid hormones (THs) play a crucial role in regulating metamorphosis, and several processes can influence TH balance, including sulfation, deiodination, and glucuronidation.
  * Environmental contaminants can disrupt TH metabolism by targeting various processes, such as inhibiting thyroidal iodide uptake, suppressing thyroidal peroxidase activity, and binding to thyroid transport proteins.
  * Amphibian metamorphosis can be divided into three stages: premetamorphosis, prometamorphosis, and climax, with each stage having distinct characteristics.
  * Exposure to thyroid-disrupting substances can lead to retardation or acceleration of metamorphosis, depending on the compound and the developmental stage of the tadpole.
  * The Amphibian Metamorphosis Assay (AMA) has been adopted by the OECD and EPA as a guideline for testing chemicals, focusing on the hypothalamic-pituitary-thyroid (HPT) axis and its role in metamorphosis.

• Cesarean sections (CS) performed following a medical indication are necessary to prevent maternal or perinatal complications.
• The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends a CS rate of 10-15% for the lowest rate of maternal and perinatal morbidity and mortality.
• However, there has been a worldwide increase in CS without medical indication, leading to higher rates of CS.
• A study found that women who undergo CS have higher severe maternal morbidity compared to planned vaginal delivery (VD).
• A prospective study was conducted to explore the impact of delivery mode on women's postpartum physical and mental health-related quality of life (HRQOL).
• The study found that women who underwent VD had better physical HRQOL at 2 and 4 months after delivery, with significant differences in physical functioning and role limitation due to physical problems.
• At 4 months after delivery, women who underwent VD also had better mental HRQOL and showed more improvements in mental HRQOL from time 1 to time 2 assessment.
• The study suggests that socio-economic deficiencies and medical problems are risk factors for decreased HRQOL and depressive symptoms during the postnatal period.
• The study recommends future studies to include both general and specific questionnaires in assessing postpartum HRQOL among women with VD, elective CS, and emergency CS, and to recognize social and cultural factors related to physical and mental HRQOL after delivery.

1. * Maslow's hierarchy of needs, proposed in 1943 and 1954, suggests that human needs can be categorized into physiological needs, safety needs, belongingness and love, esteem, and self-actualization.
2. * Physiological needs are the most fundamental requirements for survival, while safety needs include personal security, financial security, and health and well-being.
3. * Safety needs can block physiological needs, as shown in Miller's avoidance and approach experiments, where animals tend to be more sensitive to threatening information and generally process such information faster than rewarding information.
4. * The amygdala is the neural basis for fear and stress elicited fear and anxiety, and electrical stimulation of the amygdala promotes autonomous reactions and stress-like behavioral responses.
5. * The fast-acting thalamus-amygdala circuit is important for rapid recognition of dangers, and it is an evolutionary adaptation for better coping with unexpected environments.
6. * The emotion fear and anger might also be derived from the same neurotransmitter ne and the same stressful event.
7. * Safety needs are the most fundamental needs for human kind, and safety is the major reason for mental disorders such as anxiety, phobia, depression, and PTSD.
8. * The neural basis for safety is amygdala and lc/ne system, whose major behavior function is fight or flight and fear and anger emotions or conditioned learning for these emotions.

1. <summary>Epoxyeicosatrienoic acids (EETs) are autacoids that play crucial roles in various physiological functions such as blood pressure regulation, nociception, adipogenesis, anti-inflammatory activity, organ regeneration, insulin potentiation, podocyte integrity, and cellular responses to bacterial infection. The most prominent regioisomer, 14,15-EET, and other EET members arise via metabolism of arachidonic acid by cytochromes P450, especially members of the 2c and 2j families. The ratio of EET isomers and their stereocomposition are isoform-dependent and thus species- and tissue-specific.</summary>
2. <summary>Numerous chemical and metabolic factors complicate investigations into the roles of 14,15-EET and restrain its potential therapeutic utility. Its susceptibility to aerial or auto-oxidation necessitates handling and storage under strict conditions. In biological milieu, hydration of the epoxide by soluble epoxide hydrolase (sEH) is a major determinant in maintaining the steady-state levels of 14,15-EET, whose half-life has been estimated at no more than seconds to minutes. Inhibition of sEH can elevate EET levels both in vitro and in vivo, offering an indirect means for pharmacologic intervention in EET-mediated processes.</summary>
3. <summary>To address some of the stability limitations of natural EETs, researchers have prepared several iterations of EET surrogates with improved stability. These surrogates were evaluated for relaxation of precontracted bovine coronary artery rings and for in vitro inhibition of recombinant human sEH. The simple expedient of conjugating the carboxylate with a short poly(ethylene oxide) (PEG) unit improved both % vasorelaxation and the EC50 compared with the parent free acids. Linkage of the carboxylate to the nitrogen of glycine or aspartic acid resulted in a modest boost to the vasoactivities, while the SEH IC50 of aspartic acid-linked sur

1. * The Patient-Centered Medical Home (PCMH) model is a healthcare approach that aims to provide quality, coordinated, and cost-effective care to patients, and increase access to services. It is an extension of Edward Wagner's Chronic Care Model (CCM) and has been implemented in over 1,500 sites and 7,700 clinicians across the US.
2. * The transition to PCMH can be challenging, with difficulties including promoting physician buy-in, changing office culture, care coordination, staffing and space allocations, and leveraging electronic medical records (EMRs). However, successful PCMHs have seen improvements in patient care and satisfaction.
3. * To become recognized as a PCMH by the National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA), a practice must provide documentation of its guidelines for implementation and adhere to PCMH principles. This recognition increases the likelihood of reimbursement for pioneering PCMH procedures.
4. * The PCMH model emphasizes team-based care, with staff addressing patient treatment decisions collectively and care coordinators performing tasks that were previously delivered inconsistently or not at all. However, the adoption of multidisciplinary team members in patient education and support can be challenging due to issues with time, salary, responsibilities, and workload.
5. * The size of the primary care practice can be an obstacle in implementing the PCMH model, with smaller practices having a harder time making the necessary changes due to budget constraints. However, PCMH principles encourage the use of electronic medical records to increase the efficiency of care coordination.

1. <summary>The use of hypothermia therapy for patients who have suffered from cardiac arrest has been shown to improve their survival rate and neurological function, according to a meta-analysis of six randomized controlled trials. However, the therapy does not have a significant effect on survival rate and neurological function at hospital discharge.</summary>
2. <summary>The meta-analysis found that hypothermia therapy can reduce cerebral oxygen consumption and energy metabolism, reduce reactive oxygen species generation and release of excitatory amino acids, preserve the integrity of the blood-brain barrier, and regulate the gene expression of inflammatory and apoptotic proteins, which can help improve patient outcomes.</summary>
3. <summary>However, the meta-analysis also identified several limitations, including a small number of trials and study sizes, as well as clinical and methodological heterogeneity. Further research is needed to accurately determine the impact of different cooling measures or hypothermia duration on survival rate and neurological function.</summary>
4. <summary>Despite the potential side effects of hypothermia therapy, such as re-arrest and renal failure, the meta-analysis concluded that the therapy is safe for cardiac arrest patients. The pooled results showed that mild hypothermia does improve prognosis of patients and does not influence the incidence of adverse events compared with the control group.</summary>

1. Infertility can be caused by male factors, with approximately 40% of marital infertility due to male issues. Varicocele is a common male factor, characterized by enlargement and elongation of the pampiniform plexus, venous convolution, and sinus formation.
2. The exact cause of varicocele is unclear, but it is believed to be related to blood turbulence and retrograde flow of renal metabolites and adrenal hormones to the testis, leading to venous stasis, testicular hyperemia, and compromised testicular oxygen concentration.
3. High-grade varicocele can be detected through a meticulous andrologic examination, including inspection, palpation, and Doppler examination to assess pampiniform plexus diameters, presence and character of backflow, and testicular size.
4. A palpable varicocele with testicular hypotrophy on the affected side, confirmed by color Doppler, is an indication for surgical repair.
5. A retrospective study of 68 adolescents who underwent laparoscopic repair for idiopathic varicocele with testicular hypotrophy from 1996 to 2011 showed significant improvement in testicular volume and semen parameters.
6. The laparoscopic repair was performed via a transperitoneal approach with division of the testicular vein only. The evaluation of surgical outcome was based on ultrasound evidence of varicocele subsidence and increase of testicular volume on the affected side.
7. Late diagnosis and treatment of varicocele can result in spermatogenesis disturbances and abnormal concentrations of sex hormones, highlighting the importance of early detection and intervention.
8. Assessment of the efficacy of surgical varicocele repair should include hormonal tests and semen analysis in procreative age group.

* Radical retropubic prostatectomy is the standard treatment for localized prostate cancer
<summary>

  * The major long-term morbidity of the procedure is erectile dysfunction
  * Erectile dysfunction is caused by injury to the cavernosal nerves, which were identified by Walsh and Donker
  * Cavernosal nerves are located in a neurovascular bundle on the posterolateral border of the prostate
  * Nerve-sparing radical retropubic prostatectomy has improved potency rates
  * A recent study described the periprostatic nerve distribution and constructed a 3-dimensional model
  * The study found that nerve fibers are distributed evenly around the prostatic capsule, except in the ventral part
  * The ventral part of the prostate has fewer and thinner nerve fibers
  * The three-dimensional model revealed an absence of a cord-like neurovascular bundle in the ventral part
  * Recent studies have challenged the traditional knowledge of the neurovascular bundle and its distribution
</summary>

* The number of periprostatic nerve fibers is distributed evenly on both lateral and dorsal (rectal) parts from base to apex of the prostate without forming any cord-like structures
* The number of nerve fibers on the ventral part is few in comparison, so an excessive high up incision over 2, 10 o'clock on the ventral part of the prostate is insignificant during nerve-sparing radical prostatectomy.

1. * The study found that serum saa concentration was high above normal in the vast majority of ra patients, with only <10% of patients having normal saa levels. Elevated saa levels were found not only in patients with high disease activity but also in those with low or moderate disease activity, suggesting that sustained inflammation persists in most ra patients.
2. * The study demonstrated a direct relationship between saa and ra activity, with significantly higher saa associated with current treatment with gcs and women treated with biological dmards having significantly lower saa concentration than women treated only with synthetic dmards. The mean saa level was significantly higher in patients with plaques and increased cys-c level, indicating the risk of cv and renal involvement in the course of ra.
3. * The study also found that persistently elevated saa concentration increases the risk of amyloidosis development due to deposition of amyloid proteins in different tissues and organs. The saa level correlated with clinical disease activity and may be produced by rheumatoid synovial tissue, inducing cell growth, angiogenesis, invasion, and migration of cells, secretion of proinflammatory cytokines, chemokines, reactive oxygen species, and matrix metalloproteinases. Therefore, saa may play a pathogenic role locally in joint destruction and cartilage damage.

1. * Glucocorticoids, which are part of systemic stress responses, play a role in promoting inflammation and may promote Th2-type immunity through differential effects on Th1 and Th2 cytokine production.
2. * Chronic stimulation of eosinophil production (eosinopoiesis) is an important feature of human and murine asthma, and can be regulated by lymphocyte populations in nonsensitized subjects.
3. * Endogenous glucocorticoids, such as corticosterone, play a critical role in the hematological response to allergen challenge in an allergic asthma model, and can also induce short-term bone marrow eosinophilia in response to mild surgical trauma.
4. * Perforin deficiency presents a selective defect in granulocyte production, which can be corrected by wild-type lymphocyte transfer.
5. * The ability of lymphocyte preparations to reconstitute responses to dexamethasone is abolished by depletion of CD4+ and/or CD8+ cells before transfer, suggesting that different mechanisms are involved for eosinophils and neutrophils.
6. * Lymphocyte transfer restored the short-term response to dexamethasone but did not bring the baseline counts of eosinophils and neutrophils to the same level of the b6 controls, suggesting that steady-state granulopoiesis and response to dexamethasone may be unrelated processes.

1. India has a high number of Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) patients, with 62.4 million reported cases.
2. Fear of hypoglycaemia and weight gain are common barriers to insulin therapy initiation.
3. Modern insulin analogues offer a convenient approach to glycaemic control, with a lower risk of hypoglycaemia and favourable weight changes.
4. The A1chieve study, a 24-week non-interventional study, assessed the safety and effectiveness of insulin analogues in T2DM patients in routine clinical care.
5. The majority of patients started on or switched to biphasic insulin aspart, while others used insulin detemir, insulin aspart, basal insulin plus insulin aspart, or other insulin combinations.
6. After 24 weeks of treatment, hypoglycaemic events reduced in both insulin-naive and insulin user groups, and blood pressure decreased, lipid profile improved, and quality of life increased.
7. All parameters of glycaemic control improved in patients who started or switched to biphasic insulin aspart, basal + insulin aspart, insulin detemir, or insulin aspart.
8. No severe adverse events, such as major hypoglycaemic events, occurred in any study patients.
9. The study suggests that insulin analogues can be considered effective and safe for treating T2DM in Mumbai, India, although further research with larger patient numbers is needed.

- Many cell types have been studied for cardiac regeneration, including embryonic stem cells (ESCs), mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs), skeletal myoblasts, bone marrow-derived progenitor cells, induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs), and resident cardiac stem cells.
* ESCs can differentiate into cardiovascular lineages, but concerns about teratoma formation, graft-versus-host disease, and bioethics have hindered clinical trials.
* iPSCs can be generated from adult somatic cells and differentiate into functional cardiovascular lineages, offering the potential for an unlimited supply of autologous donor cells.
* MSCs can differentiate into osteoblasts, chondrocytes, adipocytes, and cardiomyocytes under special conditions. They can be rapidly expanded in culture and are less immunogenic, making them suitable for allogenic transplantation.
* Skeletal myoblasts can be harvested from muscle biopsies, expanded in culture, and autologously reimplanted. However, they do not differentiate into true cardiomyocytes in vivo, leading to dyssynchronous contractions and a lack of significant benefit in large-scale clinical trials.
* Bone marrow-derived mononuclear cells, including hematopoietic and endothelial progenitor cells, can differentiate into cardiomyocytes, endothelial cells, and smooth muscle cells in culture. Intracoronary infusion of these cells has been shown to improve left ventricular ejection fraction, decrease infarct scar size, and lower left ventricular end-systolic volume in patients with acute myocardial infarction or chronic ischemic cardiomyopathy.
* The optimal timing and dosage of bone morphogenetic protein (BMP) signaling modulation may be critical for reliable ex vivo cardiomyocyte differentiation from ESCs or mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs).
* Recent evidence suggests that adult cardiomyocytes may be induced to proliferate, providing a complementary strategy for cardiac regeneration.

1. Polyhalite is a mineral commonly found in sedimentary evaporite successions and in rare cases in volcanic successions. It was first described in Austria and has since been found in many salt deposits worldwide.
2. Polyhalite is associated with other minerals such as halite, anhydrite, glauberite, carnallite, kieserite, langbeinite, vanthoffite, chlorides, and sulphides.
3. The crystal structure of polyhalite was first determined in samples from Altaussee, Austria, and later confirmed. It can be synthesized in laboratory conditions by reacting gypsum with appropriate solutions in the ternary system K2SO4-MgSO4-H2O at temperatures above 70°C.
4. Polyhalite forms early diagenetically by brine-back reactions of K-Mg-SO4 brine with earlier formed gypsum, anhydrite, or glauberite after prolonged contact with the precursor rock.
5. Polyhalite is stable between room temperature (0-25°C) and 255-343°C, making it useful for absolute age dating in deciphering the geological history of a region.
6. In the Haselgebirge evaporites of the Northern Calcareous Alps, polyhalite is a minor but widespread and important constituent, occurring mainly intergrown with anhydrite or as vein fillings.
7. The Haselgebirge evaporites experienced maximum temperatures of 200-300°C, and polyhalite is mainly part of the red salt rock (rotsalzgebirge), which is composed of a mixture of reddish-grey salt, anhydrite, polyhalite, glauberite, Na-Mg sulphates, red and black claystones, and grey-brown sandstones.
8. The polyhalite microfabrics from Hallstatt include vein-filling, fibrous polyhalite of likely middle to late Triassic age, polyhalite mylonites of early Cretaceous age, metamorphic reaction fabrics of a post-early Cretaceous age, and cavity-filling polyhalite

* Oxidative stress, caused by an imbalance between free radical production and antioxidant defense, is a critical factor in the development of several systemic diseases.
 * Propofol, a widely used anesthetic, has antioxidant effects and has been shown to ameliorate oxidative injury in various organs.
 * The effects of high-dose propofol on the lipid profile, cardiovascular marker enzymes, and enzymatic and nonenzymatic antioxidant indices in rodents have not been determined.
 * In this study, rats were treated with propofol at a human therapeutic dose (2 mg/kg) and twice the therapeutic dose (4 mg/kg) for four weeks.
 * The results showed that propofol increased the levels of serum total cholesterol, triglycerides, and LDL cholesterol, while decreasing HDL cholesterol levels.
 * The increased cholesterol level may be linked to an increase in alpha-hydroxyl methyl glutaryl coenzyme A reductase activity, which is the rate-limiting step in cholesterol biosynthesis.
 * Propofol also increased the activities of hepatic glutathione peroxidase and glutathione-S-transferase, indicating an increased detoxifying and antioxidant capability of the liver.
 * However, propofol treatment significantly increased the activities of serum lactate dehydrogenase and creatinine phosphokinase, which are markers of muscle and heart lesion.
 * The study suggests that the use of propofol in patients with cardiovascular or lipid disorders should be carefully reviewed.

1. * Idiopathic hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (IHH) is a rare genetic disorder caused by deficiency of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) release from the hypothalamus.
2. * A study was conducted in China to collect clinical data of IHH patients through a network questionnaire and their medical records, and compared the data with previous studies to improve understanding, diagnosis, and treatment of IHH.
3. * The study found that hormone replacement therapy improved the conditions of IHH patients effectively, and the commonly used gonadotropin + androgen therapy appeared to be superior to androgen replacement alone.
4. * The study also found that the therapeutic effect in g + a group was superior to that in g group with respect to the penis length, pubic hair growth, testosterone normalization rate, and self-assessment scores of physical strength.
5. * The study suggests that disease-specific network investigation can be used as an alternative method of medical research, but its effectiveness needs to be further verified.

* Nonsurgical endodontic retreatment is the primary choice to eliminate or reduce microbial content in endodontically failed teeth.
 * Well-compacted root fillings can make retreatment difficult by resisting instruments and leaving residues, which can lead to postoperative inflammation and impaired healing due to extruded irritants.
 * The study compares the apical debris extrusion of three supplementary files (PTN, Wo, and Saf) used after the Protaper Universal RFS for removing residual root canal fillings.
 * The null hypothesis is that there will be no significant differences in the amount of debris extruded by the three files.
 * The teeth were cleaned, shaped, and filled using specific instruments and materials, and then kept for 30 days to allow complete setting of the sealer.
 * Following this, the teeth were randomly divided into four experimental groups for retreatment, and the apical debris extruded was collected and weighed.
 * The statistical results showed that Wo was associated with a 27% increase in debris extrusion, Ptn with a 19% increase, and Saf with a 12% increase when used as supplementary files after using the Protaper Universal RFS.

1. * The anterior and middle superior alveolar (AMSA) nerve block is a proposed anesthetic technique for maxillary teeth that claims to achieve pulpal anesthesia from the central incisor to the second premolar through a single palatal injection, without causing lip numbness or interference with facial muscles.* This technique is derived from the diffusion of the anesthetic solution via numerous nutrient channels on the palatal process of the maxillary bone, targeting the anterior and middle superior alveolar nerves.* However, studies have reported varying success rates with this technique, and its application in clinical practice may depend on factors such as the presence of the middle superior alveolar nerve and the use of computer-controlled injection systems.

1. Malaria is a serious public health problem in South-East Asia, including India, with the majority of cases in India (76%) and a significant portion of the population living in high transmission areas.
2. A community-based descriptive cross-sectional study in Rs Pura health block of Jammu district in Jammu and Kashmir state in North India found that the majority of study participants had adequate knowledge about malaria transmission, symptoms, prevention, and treatment.
3. The study also found that the majority of study participants considered malaria to be a serious health problem and had a positive attitude towards the use of bed nets and vector control programs. However, knowledge does not always translate to better preventive measures, and low literacy levels and poor socioeconomic status may be barriers to effective malaria prevention.

1. The dynamic folding of the chromatin, including the formation of chromosome territories, genomic compartments, and topologically associating domains (TADs), is crucial for regulating gene expression and DNA replication during development. TADs, which range from 100 kb to 1 mb in size, exhibit higher frequency of physical contacts between genes and their regulatory regions and are stable across different species, cell types, and conditions. The boundaries of TADs are associated with specific histone marks, the timing of replication domains, and the enrichment of certain proteins, such as CTCF, cohesin, and DNase I hypersensitivity sites. These boundaries serve as barriers to long- and short-range interactions between DNA sequences, and their strength is influenced by the binding of insulators and the effects of enzymes that modify or remodel chromatin.
2. The major ATPase subunit of the SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complex, Brg1 (also known as Smarca4), is required for proper nucleosome occupancy and positioning at target regions and for establishing numerous long-range chromatin interactions. A recent study found that Brg1 contributes to TAD boundary strength and that its loss affects nucleosome occupancy and higher-order chromatin organization. Specifically, Brg1 knockdown in human mammary epithelial MCF-10a cells resulted in the differential expression of genes related to extracellular matrix and lipid synthesis, as well as many long non-coding RNAs, which are involved in genome organization. Additionally, Brg1 binds primarily to genic regions and intergenic super-enhancers, which are clusters of regulatory regions with unusual enrichment of factor binding sites and/or histone modifications.
3. Comparison of control and Brg1 knockdown Hi-C data sets revealed that the majority of TAD boundaries were largely overlapping between the two groups, but more than 10% of the boundaries were unique to either the control or the Brg1 knockdown cells. The strength of the TAD boundaries was significantly reduced in Brg1 knockdown cells, resulting in a higher frequency of inter-TAD genomic interactions. This effect was more pronounced for TAD boundaries that were bound by Brg1, as their strength was stronger than the

1. The study uses statistical modeling, specifically Poisson and negative binomial regressions with zero inflated, to analyze the number of failed courses and semesters among students at Iran University of Medical Sciences. The study found that the university average and quota system have an inverse relationship with the number of failed semesters, meaning that an increase in university average and changing from other quota system to free quota system can decrease the number of failed semesters. Additionally, an increase in the number of failed courses can increase the chance of having failed semesters.
2. In the Poisson regression model, the variables of gender and marital status have an inverse and positive relationship with the number of failed courses, respectively. This means that the number of failed courses is higher in males than females and in singles than married students. However, in negative binomial regression, the variables of bachelor level and the faculties of management and rehabilitation caused an increase in the number of failed courses.
3. The study found that the university average has an important role in reducing the number of failed courses, and increasing the number of bachelor and master students can also help reduce the number of failed courses. Additionally, an increase in the number of failed semesters can decrease the logarithm of zero inflated in both models, but the amounts of these changes are different. The study was supported by Iran University of Medical Sciences under the grant number of 370.

1. * Electrostatic interactions play a crucial role in enzyme catalysis, assisting in ligand binding and facilitating enzyme-catalyzed chemical reactions by positioning and stabilizing reacting species.
2. * Conformational changes during the catalytic cycle can significantly modulate these electrostatic interactions, affecting the electrostatic environment in the active site.
3. * The authors studied the changes in the active site electrostatic environment in Escherichia coli dihydrofolate reductase (ecdhfr) during its catalytic cycle using thiocyanate probes, vibrational and NMR spectroscopy, and computer simulations.
4. * The electrostatic interactions arising from the active site microenvironments led to different observed CN vibrational stretching frequencies and CNMR chemical shifts along the catalytic cycle.
5. * Mixed quantum mechanical and molecular mechanical (QM/MM) analyses of classical molecular dynamics (MD) simulations reproduced experimentally measured vibrational frequency shifts, revealing the contributions of individual residues and ligands to the electric field along the hydride transfer pathway.
6. * The study highlights the interplay between electrostatic and conformational changes along the catalytic cycle, providing valuable insights for understanding enzyme catalysis.
7. * The experimental and theoretical data suggest significant electrostatic changes in the microenvironments that constitute the heterogeneous ecdhfr active site as the enzyme progresses along the catalytic cycle.
8. * The electrostatic interactions between the protein and the ligands assist in orienting the reacting species in a geometry that maintains a large electric field favoring hydride transfer from the cofactor to the substrate, emphasizing the catalytic importance of enzymatic conformational changes that alter the active site electrostatics.

1. The text discusses the use of Magnetic Particle Imaging (MPI) as a new three-dimensional imaging method that uses static and dynamic magnetic fields to visualize the distribution of superparamagnetic iron oxide nanoparticles (SPIONs). MPI can provide very high temporal and spatial resolution with high signal-to-noise ratios. Possible application scenarios for MPI include cardiovascular imaging and guidance of cardiovascular interventions.
2. The text also discusses the importance of suitable tracer material for MPI, specifically long-circulating SPIONs that can provide a sufficient signal within the vessels after a single tracer injection. The circulation time of SPIONs in blood is mainly determined by their overall hydrodynamic diameter, which is influenced by the size of the iron oxide core and the coatings. However, previous reports have shown that SPIONs with a hydrodynamic size greater than 50 nm have rapid and specific uptake by the reticuloendothelial system and are cleared rapidly from the blood stream.
3. The text also compares the properties of Resovist, an approved T2* contrast agent for MRI, as a benchmark material for MPI. While Resovist is the best performing commercial SPION for MPI, its hydrodynamic diameter is greater than 50 nm, which limits its in vivo distribution. The text also discusses the importance of understanding the pharmacokinetics of Resovist, especially its half-life in blood, in the context of cardiovascular MPI.

1. <summary>The study examines the transcriptomic response of uninfected and infected Kupffer cells (KCs) in the liver of mice infected with Leishmania donovani. The study found that infected KCs have a distinct transcriptional response compared to other mononuclear host cells, and that in vitro experiments may not fully capture the complexity of the in vivo response.</summary>
2. <summary>The study also found that uninfected KCs undergo significant biological and gene transcriptional changes in response to the inoculation of live Leishmania donovani amastigotes, suggesting that soluble mediators or signals operating in trans facilitate global activation of macrophages within the infected tissue.</summary>
3. <summary>The study identified and validated the importance of a gene network centered around RXRA that is associated with the survival of amastigotes within the liver of Leishmania donovani-infected mice. The network has not previously been implicated in Leishmania donovani pathogenesis in mice, but other studies have observed changes in lipid metabolism genes associated with Leishmania infection.</summary>
4. <summary>The study also highlights the potential of using cells exposed to inflammation as a powerful method for the discovery of pathogen-regulated gene pathways, and the potential of targeting nuclear receptors for therapy in Leishmaniasis.</summary>

1. The control of appetite is complex and involves both physiological and environmental factors.
2. Early theories focused on signals from glucose metabolism, amino acids, or adipose tissue, while more recent models emphasize inputs from adipose tissue and the gastrointestinal tract.
3. Major signals include leptin from adipose tissue and hormones from specialized cells in the gastrointestinal tract.
4. A new formulation suggests that body composition and energy expenditure regulate hunger and appetite.
5. The relationship between energy expenditure and energy intake is also important in appetite regulation.
6. Exercise can have various effects on appetite through changes in heart rate, blood flow, sympathetic nervous system activity, gut hormone activity, and nutrient absorption.
7. A single acute bout of exercise has different effects on appetite compared to continued daily sessions of exercise.
8. Detailed analysis of body composition and appetite variables has shown that fat-free mass (ffm) is strongly correlated with meal size and daily energy intake, suggesting that privileged molecules or physiological consequences of ffm act as a signal to drive food intake.

1. * Polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) is a commonly used material in prosthetic dentistry for denture base fabrication due to its desirable properties such as esthetics, low water sorption, and simple processing technique.
2. * The conventional heat-polymerized PMMA resin technique is widely used, but it has disadvantages such as dimensional changes and inaccuracies in the fit of the denture base. Chemically activated resins, when compression molded, display less polymerization shrinkage and greater dimensional accuracy.
3. * The injection molding technique has advantages over the compression molding technique, including reduced processing time, lower cost, lower skin sensitivity, and availability of the resin reservoir to compensate for acrylic resin shrinkage.
4. * The type of processing can affect the mechanical properties of the resins, such as the bond strength between the denture teeth and the denture base resins. Debonding of denture teeth from denture bases is a major problem in prosthodontic practice.
5. * Surface treatments of the denture teeth, such as grinding the glossy ground surface, painting the ground surface of the teeth with monomer, and cutting mechanical retention features in the ground surface of the teeth, can increase the bond strength between acrylic resin teeth and denture base resins.

* Arc welding emits intense ultraviolet radiation (UVR) which can cause acute and delayed health effects, including keratoconjunctivitis, erythema, cataracts, and skin cancer.
 * A survey of 1667 workers at workplaces where arc welding is performed found that 86% had experienced symptoms of uv keratoconjunctivitis, and 45% reported ongoing experience with this ailment. The uvr hazard tends to increase with welding current and is dependent on the type of welding wire. The study also found that the uvr emitted during gmaw performed with a digital inverter-type pulsed arc welding machine was hazardous, with effective irradiance in the range of 3.4 - 11.6 mw / cm. The allowable daily exposure times corresponding to these values are just 0.23 - 5.9 s, which are extremely short times. Therefore, it is necessary to take precautions to ensure that surrounding workers are not exposed to the uvr emitted by the arc.

1. Many microorganisms, including bacteria and archaea, can produce polyhydroxyalkanoates (PHAs) as energy and carbon storage compounds, which can increase their survival capabilities in extreme environments or when nutrient availability is poor.
2. PHAs are divided into two groups based on the number of carbon atoms in their monomer units: short-chain-length (SCL) PHAs and medium-chain-length (MCL) PHAs.
3. The type of PHA produced and accumulated in the granules depends on the metabolic pathway of the particular microorganism, and the enzyme called PHA synthase plays a major role in PHA synthesis.
4. A study was conducted to determine whether bacteria inhabiting freshwater reservoirs in glacier forefield areas in Antarctica have the potential to synthesize PHAs.
5. Samples were collected from five shallow freshwater reservoirs and one stream, and the partial 16S rRNA gene was amplified using primers 341 and 16sr.
6. The study found that many of the isolated strains possessed genes responsible for PHAs synthesis, particularly strains belonging to the Pseudomonas and Janthinobacterium genera. The results suggest that PHA metabolism in Antarctic strains could be an adaptation mechanism to withstand harsh conditions in polar regions.

1. Reclaiming arid and semi-arid lands involves modifying topography, creating appropriate surface composition, and establishing vegetation, with the latter being the most uncertain category.
2. Vegetation establishment is important for reducing erosion, improving public perception, allowing for productive reuse of land, and reintegrating disturbed lands into the existing landscape.
3. Uncertainty in vegetation establishment comes primarily from reliance on unpredictable rainfall for germination and establishment.
4. Irrigation can benefit exotic weeds more than natives and is generally not more successful due to the need for high intensity/long duration water application.
5. Natural rainfall can allow the establishment of robust native or non-native vegetation, with natives now more recommended due to their long-term stability, resource value for wildlife, and better public acceptance.
6. A mixed plant community is needed to maximize the long-term positive impact of re-vegetation, with perennial grasses often being the primary contributors to surface stability and erosion prevention.
7. The study aims to estimate how frequently native perennial warm-season grasses may be established in southern Arizona using 31 years of historical rainfall event data.
8. The study used a land surface model driven by hourly atmospheric forcing data and calibrated the model's hydraulic parameters to match observed soil moisture and surface energy and water fluxes from flux tower data.
9. The study found that the worst 10-year span for seeding success was between 1986 and 1995 for gage 5, where six of ten plantings would have failed, and the best 10-year span was between 1998 and 2007 for gage 6, where only one of ten was projected to fail.
10. The study showed six times more potential for seeding success (68%) than was expected from the 10% estimate by Cox and Jordan (1983) for southern Arizona, indicating substantial potential for reclamation in most years. However, there are numerous factors such as germination response, root growth, and other sources of mortality that bear further consideration.

• Major depression (MD) is a major cause of disability and is projected to be the second leading contributor to the global burden of disease by 2020.
• Up to 40% of patients with MD do not respond to available antidepressant medications, and this treatment-resistant depression (TRD) can lead to suicide.
• There are several staging methods for TRD that help researchers and clinicians understand and plan interventions for patients.
• There is increasing interest in the use of neuromodulation therapies (NTS) for TRD, as they target specific brain circuits and have fewer side effects compared to psychopharmacological therapy.
• NTS include seizure therapies, noninvasive therapies, neurosurgical approaches, and new approaches on the horizon.
• Studies have shown that deep brain stimulation (DBS) can modulate neural pathways linked with overactive subcallosal cingulate gyrus (SCG) glucose metabolism in MD, and can also have antidepressant effects when targeted at other brain regions.
• Modified electroconvulsive therapy (MECT) is an effective therapy for TRD, but it has a high post-treatment relapse rate and safety concerns.
• Research is needed to develop strategies to prevent relapse following successful MECT and to identify predictors of nonresponse to MECT.
• There are challenges in conducting research on somatic therapies for TRD, including the lack of a universally accepted definition of TRD, the need for larger and more diverse study samples, and the need for comparative research with antidepressant drugs.

1. Small RNA molecules are important in regulating various molecular and biological activities in the cell, and RNA interference (RNAi) is a widely recognized gene regulatory mechanism that causes sequence-specific downregulation of mRNAs.
2. Double-stranded short interfering RNAs (siRNAs) can knock down expression levels via the RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC), which mediates degradation or translational inhibition of the targeted mRNAs.
3. In addition to RISC-mediated regulation at the post-transcriptional level, RNAi can also modulate gene transcription itself.
4. In fission yeast, homologs of the RNA-induced silencing complex can regulate chromatin through recruitment of histone-modifying proteins to loci transcribing small noncoding RNA.
5. Small promoter-targeted RNAs have been shown to repress transcription and induce epigenetic changes in eukaryotic cells through a mechanism called transcriptional gene silencing.
6. In human cells, short RNAs targeted to the promoter regions of certain genes can activate expression at the transcriptional level, a phenomenon called RNA activation (RNAA), which has been conserved in other mammalian species.
7. Promoter-targeted small hairpin RNAs have been shown to efficiently upregulate genes in vivo through a mechanism involving naturally occurring antisense transcripts and Argonaute proteins.

1. Microglia, which were once thought to play no role in the immune system of the central nervous system (CNS), are now known to be crucial for innate immunity within the CNS. They are derived from erythromyeloid progenitors in the yolk sac and invade the developing brain during embryogenesis.
2. The CNS immune system is more active than previously believed, with the presence of a glymphatic system that enables communication between the brain parenchyma and cervical lymph nodes. This system, along with brain microglia, facilitates immune surveillance of brain interstitial fluid.
3. CSD (cortical spreading depression), a slowly propagating wave of neural and glial depolarization, has been shown to induce inflammatory activation of microglia. This activation can lead to the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and tumor necrosis factor (TNF), which can lower the threshold for CSD induction and form a positive feedback mechanism that favors its perpetuation.

1. Transposable elements (TEs) were once considered junk DNA, but they have been shown to serve as a genomic reservoir for new regulatory and coding sequences, allowing genetic innovation and organismal evolution. They can be molecularly domesticated to form new cellular protein-coding genes. TE-encoded proteins have properties that can be of interest for host cellular pathways, such as binding, copying, cutting, processing, and recombining nucleic acids, as well as modifying and interacting with host proteins.
2. There are many cases of TE-derived genes fulfilling important functions in plants, fungi, and animals, including vertebrates. For example, several multigenic families have been formed from different events of molecular domestication of the gag gene of Ty3/gypsy elements, a super family of LTR retrotransposons active in fish and amphibians but extinct in mammals. These genes encode a structural protein with three functional regions: the matrix (ma) domain playing a role in targeting cellular membranes, the capsid (ca) domain involved in interactions with other proteins during particle assembly, and the nucleocapsid (nc), which binds to viral RNA genomes through zinc fingers.
3. Molecular domestication of TEs has played an important role in the evolution of specific sublineages within vertebrates. For example, gin genes, a pair of ancient vertebrate domesticated genes for which no function has been identified so far, have been detected in mammals, birds, and reptiles (gin1) and tetrapods, bony fish, and sharks (gin2). The presence of both genes over such long periods of evolution suggests important, so far unknown conserved functions in vertebrates. Gin2 was lost in a common ancestor of monotremes and placental mammals, indicating that either gin2 function was not essential anymore or that this function is fulfilled now by gin1 in these sublineages.

1. <summary>\* Progressive diseases, such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's, affect millions of people worldwide and are caused by the misfolding and aggregation of specific proteins.
* These diseases can spread from cell to cell and amplify over time, leading to a self-sustaining cycle that results in disease.
* Molecular chaperones play a crucial role in preventing protein misfolding and aggregation, but can become imbalanced during cellular stress, leading to the formation of protein deposits.
* Protein aggregates can cause both loss of function and gain of pathologic function, leading to a variety of symptoms and diseases.
* Fibrillar protein aggregates are a hallmark of many neurodegenerative diseases, and their formation and spread can be replicated in vitro.
* The toxicity of protein assemblies is due in part to their binding to and permeabilization of the cell membrane, which can lead to further cell damage and dysfunction.</summary>

 * However, a significant association was observed between gln27glu polymorphism of βAR and ischemic stroke when assuming either recessive or dominant models of inheritance.

 * Further well-designed larger prospective cohort studies are required to validate these findings and establish the underlying molecular causal pathways that confer susceptibility to ischemic stroke.

7. The meta-analysis found an 80% reduction in ovarian/fallopian tube cancer risk and a 50% reduction in breast cancer risk associated with RRSO in women with BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations.
8. The analysis also found that modeling studies have demonstrated that salpingo-oophorectomy has a large effect on years of life added, particularly when adjusted for quality of life.

1. * The isolation of pure cell populations is essential in clinical and basic research, such as in the diagnostic test for HIV infection and in research on the body's response to injury.

3. * Micro- and nanotechnology offer advantages over conventional cell separation techniques, such as small sample volumes, portability, low cost, improved sterility, and potential integration with analytical techniques.
4. * Size-based and affinity-based techniques are the two main categories of cell separation methods. Examples of micro- and nanotechnology-based size-based techniques include those that use microfluidic devices with obstacles of varied size to separate particles based on their size.
5. * Purity and throughput are important metrics for any separation process, and it is often impossible to attain high levels of both. Several novel size-based separation processes are being employed in micro- and nanoscale devices, which are compact, simple, and do not require additional energy sources or equipment.
6. * The main advantage of size-based approaches is that they do not require the presence of cell-specific markers or proteins to achieve separation, making them useful for isolating stem cells and other rare cells that do not express known markers. * The healthcare industry is facing challenges with access, cost, and quality of care, similar to other industries.
* Research-based institutions are experiencing significant stress due to competition for less funding, resulting in fewer grants, discoveries, and talented researchers leaving.
* Increasing the efficiency and effectiveness of investments in fundamental research and development is crucial to improve people's health worldwide.
* Successful innovation in healthcare requires navigating a long and challenging journey between unmet needs and a viable commercial product or service.
* The "valley of death" between academic research and commercialization is a key obstacle for health innovations, often caused by non-economic investments and lack of a promising commercialization pathway.
* Financial investors are less willing to take risks and expect a clear commercial value proposition and market potential.
* Many academic investigators are not prepared or motivated to think beyond their work in the lab to address commercial issues.
* Healthcare Commercialization Programs (HCPs) aim to strike a balance by cost-effectively advancing a project into commercialization while building the skills of team members.
* HCPs should differ from the I-Corps program to address unique needs and challenges of healthcare innovators, such as buying dynamics, reimbursement complexity, regulatory pathway, culture, and funding requirements.

1. Valerie Oppenheimer's theory on how men's socioeconomic position influences demographic change, particularly in marriage formation, is discussed. Her theory challenged the popular idea in the 1980s and 1990s that blamed the decline in marriage on the growing economic role of women.
2. Oppenheimer's theory emphasized the importance of men's economic position in marriage and family formation, which remains a vital concern given the recent economic crisis and growing economic inequality in the US and Europe.
3. The text also discusses two other theories that tried to explain the decline in marriage: the economic perspective, which saw marriage as incompatible with symmetrical gender roles, and the cultural perspective, which saw marriage as incompatible with individualistic values.
4. Oppenheimer criticized both perspectives and presented an alternative theory that focused on men's economic position. She argued that the deteriorating economic prospects of young men, especially those with little schooling, could help explain the decline in marriage.
5. The text also discusses the role of employment and income in union formation in Europe, as well as the differences in the effects of men's economic position on union formation between traditional and egalitarian societies.

<summary>

- Osteoporosis in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) is caused by a combination of factors, including motor disability, reduced bone load, long-term glucocorticoid (GCS) treatment, hypovitaminosis D, and inflammation. The level of motor disability and reduced bone load are the most significant etiology of bone loss in patients with MS.
- There are currently no specific recommendations for diagnostic or therapeutic interventions in patients with MS. However, identifying and treating the underlying cause should be the goal of therapeutic management. Early identification and preventive treatment of patients at a higher risk of osteoporosis can help avoid bone loss and fractures. Interventions that counteract osteocyte apoptosis, as well as loss of muscle mass and muscle weakness, are promising.

</summary>

1. Malaria is a major global health issue, caused by parasites in the genus Plasmodium, and transmitted through the bite of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes. The most prevalent species are P. falciparum, P. vivax, and P. malariae, with P. ovale and P. knowlesi also reported in certain regions. The text describes a study conducted in the municipality of Mâncio Lima, in the western Brazilian Amazon, to evaluate the frequency of symptoms commonly occurring in vivax malaria before and after treatment and the frequency of side effects reported during antimalarial treatment with chloroquine and primaquine.
2. The study found that chloroquine and primaquine can lead to the onset of symptoms and intensify or reduce some of the symptoms of malaria. After initiation of treatment, there was a significant reduction in the prevalence of fever, arthralgia, back pain, and retroocular pain, but a significant increase in the frequency of nausea, diarrhea, pale stools, abdominal pain, bitter taste in the mouth, weakness, and hypochondrial pain. The frequency of choluria (dark urine) also increased significantly after initiation of antimalarial treatment.

1. Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) and erectile dysfunction (ED) often appear together in elderly men, and there is a strong correlation between the two conditions. This coexistence can negatively impact quality of life. The pathophysiological mechanism behind this correlation is not fully understood, but several hypotheses have been proposed, including overactivation of the autonomic nervous system and increased tension of the sympathetic nervous system.
2. A study was conducted to examine the effects on erectile function of a combination of the alpha-blocker tamsulosin to improve LUTS and the antimuscarinic agent solifenacin to improve irritative symptoms of the bladder. Male patients aged 40 years or older who had concurrent LUTS/BPH and ED were enrolled in the study. The results showed that concomitant administration of alpha-blockers and anticholinergics improved LUTS more effectively in patients with LUTS/BPH, and this improvement was also associated with a positive effect on sexual function.
3. The use of anticholinergic agents (or antimuscarinic agents) in patients with LUTS/BPH has been attempted to improve storage symptoms due to overactive bladder (OAB). While these agents have been shown to be effective and safe in improving LUTS, there is concern that they may lead to aggravation of voiding difficulty or the development of urinary retention. However, a study of 39 men with BPH and LUTS found no significant impairment in sexual function after administration of anticholinergic agents. In patients with LUTS/BPH and ED, concomitant use of tamsulosin and solifenacin was effective for improving LUTS, but sexual function was not significantly improved by the concomitant administration of alpha-blockers and antimuscarinics.

• MicroRNAs (miRNAs) have been found to be expressed in a cell type-specific manner, during specific developmental stages, and in disease states including cancer. They can act as oncogenes or tumor suppressors during cancer initiation and progression. Differences in miRNA expression profiles have been documented in normal compared to cancerous tissue of the endometrium, breast, and ovary. miRNAs can affect the expression of proteins involved in pathways relevant to cancer, such as apoptosis, migration, and metastasis, making them promising biomarkers for several types of cancer.

• The epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) is a normal process during development, but it is also thought to be used by cancer cells during tumor progression to become more motile and metastatic. EMT involves reprogramming of the cells by transcription factors such as Zeb1, Zeb2, Twist, Snail, and Slug. A hallmark of EMT is loss of E-cadherin expression, loss of polarity, acquisition of mesenchymal markers, and increased motility. The miR-200 family, which includes miR-200c, has been implicated in the process of EMT. These miRNAs repress Zeb1 and Zeb2, which in turn repress E-cadherin. The mutual repression between miR-200c and Zeb1 creates a double negative feedback loop that allows for plasticity between the epithelial and mesenchymal states. This paper focuses on the role of miR-200c in breast, ovarian, and endometrial cancers.

• The transobturator approach for treating female stress urinary incontinence using a midurethral sling (MUS) was first described by Delorme as an alternative to the retropubic approach to reduce complications. Two variations of the transobturator approach are the outside-in and inside-out methods.
• A meta-analysis found similar cure rates for the three most commonly used surgical approaches for treating stress urinary incontinence: retropubic, outside-in transobturator, and inside-out transobturator MUS procedures. Anatomical studies have confirmed the safety of the obturator approaches in relation to neurovascular structures, but traditional anatomical dissections do not allow for the study of the MUS's configuration in relation to the urethra.
• A cadaveric study was conducted to compare the specific relationship between the tape and the urethra in both the inside-out and outside-in approaches using CT scan image analysis after tantalum wire marked mesh slings were implanted in a series of cadavers. The results showed that the out-in MUS had a mean full inner angle of 144 (95%CI: 131-151) compared to 122 (95%CI: 107-136) for the in-out MUS (p = 0.02).
• The use of tantalum wires threaded through the polypropylene-/prolene-tape in combination with three-dimensional CT-scanning yielded a unique method to visualize midurethral tapes throughout the entirety of their trajectory. This technique can be applied to different types of non-radio-opaque implants, allowing for a better spatial understanding of the anatomical position within the pelvis.

1. The Children, Young People and Education Committee is holding a post-legislative scrutiny session on the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015.
2. Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, and Huw Morris, director of the skills, higher education and lifelong learning group in Welsh Government, are in attendance.
3. The committee is discussing whether the 2015 Act will be repealed or amended by the post-compulsory education and training Bill.
4. The Act has four main objectives: regulation of institutions in Wales, safeguarding the contribution made to public good, maintaining a focus on fair access, and preserving and protecting the principle of institutional autonomy.
5. The committee is discussing whether the legislation itself has not been strong enough, and whether the objectives have been fulfilled.
6. The committee is also discussing the regulation of private providers and the requirement of being a charity.
7. The committee is considering whether national outcomes should be set through legislation, given that there is public money going into higher education.
8. The committee is discussing the use of the remit letter as a mechanism for ensuring that national priorities are clearly articulated and acted upon.
9. The committee is discussing the relationship between institutional autonomy and appropriate regulation and accountability of institutions for their public funding.
10. The committee is discussing the possibility of introducing a system of outcome agreements in the new legislation.

1. Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, and Huw Morris, director of the skills, higher education and lifelong learning group in Welsh Government, discussed the post-legislative scrutiny of the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2

* Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, and Huw Morris, director of the skills, higher education and lifelong learning group in Welsh Government, attended a post-legislative scrutiny session on the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015.
  * The Welsh Government is planning to repeal the 2015 higher education Act and replace it with the post-compulsory education and training Bill.
  * The 2015 Act was introduced to regulate institutions in Wales, safeguard the contribution made to public good, maintain fair access, and preserve institutional autonomy.
  * The Welsh Government is considering strengthening the legislation to better achieve these objectives and to regulate the post-compulsory sector as a whole.
  * The current legislation requires private providers to be charities, which makes it difficult to regulate alternative private providers. The Welsh Government is considering how this part of the sector will be regulated in the forthcoming Bill.
  * The Welsh Government is not currently planning to regulate part-time and postgraduate fees in the new legislation.
  * The 2012 university funding system has limited the Welsh Government's policy leverage over the sector, but the HE Act has provided HEFCW with new powers of intervention and sanctions.
  * The Welsh Government is determined to ensure that tertiary education providers contribute to national goals and outcomes as part of a civic mission.
  * The Welsh Government is considering giving the proposed new PCET funding body more effective policy levers to align the sector to the social, economic, and civic needs of Wales.
  * The HE Act did not encourage collaboration between institutions, and the Welsh Government is planning to introduce the new PCET reforms to create a framework that demands and encourages collaboration across the sector.

4. Sian Gwenllian AM asked whether the legislation itself hasn't been strong enough and that the objectives have had to be driven through the annual remit letter. The Minister stated that she sees the remit letter as a really important mechanism for ensuring that national priorities are clearly articulated and change happens.
5. Sian Gwenllian AM asked whether the legislation has been framed around institutional autonomy so that it's not possible for institutions to fulfil any national outcomes. The Minister stated that they will look to see how they can carry those protections into the forthcoming Bill, but at the same time ensure appropriate regulation and accountability of institutions for their public funding.
6. Sian Gwenllian AM asked whether there should be national outcomes being set through legislation, because there is public money going into that. The Minister stated that they will look to move to a system of outcome agreements, where those outputs will reflect national priorities.

It is geographically targeted and offers a range of services, including health visiting, speech and language therapy, and childcare. The program aims to create a more joined-up and responsive system that supports children and parents in the early years.

The program is demand-led and has been taken up by 94% of respondents who were already using formal childcare before the offer came into place. The Welsh Government is planning to extend the offer to parents who are in education and training and is currently reviewing the program to ensure it meets the needs of parents and children.

1. The Welsh Government has been working with higher education (HE) and further education (FE) institutions to understand the potential impact of Brexit and prepare for different scenarios.
2. The Government's White Paper, 'Securing Wales' Future', outlines its approach to Brexit and its impact on the education sector.
3. The prospect of a 'no deal' Brexit has become more likely, and officials have been visiting individual institutions to assess their preparedness.
4. The Government has been engaging with the Department for Exiting the European Union and other departments to discuss Brexit-related issues.
5. The student voice is considered in the Government's discussions with HE and FE institutions through its close relationship with the National Union of Students.
6. The Government is working to ensure stability and security for EU students, faculty, and the diversity of the student population in HE institutions.
7. The Government is also working to maintain Erasmus+ arrangements and Horizon 2020 participation, as well as post-study work visas for international students.
8. The Welsh Government has a European transition team that provides governance and coordinates Brexit-related work across departments.
9. The FE sector is locally anchored and has a lower number of EU students and staff compared to HE institutions.
10. The Government is engaging with FE colleges and ColegauCymru to understand the potential impact of Brexit on ESF funding and apprenticeships.

1. The Welsh Children, Young People and Education Committee held an evidence session on the impact of Brexit on higher and further education, with Kirsty Williams, Cabinet Secretary for Education, and Eluned Morgan AM, Minister for Welsh Language and Lifelong Learning.
2. The session covered preparedness for Brexit, including the potential impact of a 'no deal' scenario on higher education institutions and further education colleges in Wales.
3. The Welsh Government has been working closely with higher education and further education institutions to understand the potential impact of Brexit and to mitigate risks.
4. There are concerns about the impact of Brexit on European Union students and staff in Welsh higher education institutions, as well as on European social fund funding for further education colleges.
5. The Welsh Government has a European transition team in place to coordinate its response to Brexit and to work with the UK Government and other stakeholders.
6. The student voice is being taken into account in discussions between the Welsh Government, higher education funding council, and higher education institutions.
7. The Welsh Government is working to ensure that Wales remains an attractive destination for international students, including through the Global Wales programme.
8. The Welsh Government is advocating for a separate immigration system for international and EU students who may wish to study in Wales.

• Kirsty Williams, Cabinet Secretary for Education, and Eluned Morgan AM, Minister for Welsh Language and Lifelong Learning, discussed the impact of Brexit on higher and further education in Wales.
• They were asked about the preparedness of higher education institutions for Brexit and the potential impact of a "no deal" scenario. Huw Morris, group director at SHELL, mentioned that each institution has different exposure and potential impact, and that there has been ongoing work to refine approaches as the situation in London and Europe becomes clearer.
• There was a discussion about the availability of formal risk assessments for scrutiny, and Kirsty Williams mentioned that officers have been visiting each institution to ensure they have their own plans in place to deal with Brexit scenarios.
• Eluned Morgan discussed the specific impact on further education, mentioning that the number of EU students in these colleges is significantly lower and that the real problems are probably in relation to ESF funding and apprenticeships.
• Suzy Davies AM asked about the European transition team, which Marie Knox, deputy director overseeing European transition, mentioned is the central coordinating group that pulls together all the leads in each department who are pulling together the work on European transition.
• The committee also discussed the student voice in the discussion and engagement, and Kirsty Williams mentioned that they have a close working relationship with the National Union of Students and that there is a consensus about what is important across the Government, the institutions, and the students.

1. The Children, Young People and Education Committee held an evidence session on the impact of Brexit on higher and further education, with Kirsty Williams, Cabinet Secretary for Education, and Eluned Morgan AM, Minister for Welsh Language and Lifelong Learning.
2. The session covered preparedness for Brexit, including the potential impact of a "no deal" scenario on higher and further education institutions, and the steps being taken to mitigate risks.
3. There have been nine sector analyses on the impact of Brexit, including one on higher education, and ongoing work is being done to refine approaches as the situation evolves.
4. The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales has been doing specific work on Brexit, and officers have been visiting each institution to ensure they have their own plans in place.
5. The Welsh Government is working with officials in Westminster on the impacts of a "no deal" scenario on Erasmus+ provision and Horizon 2020.
6. The National Union of Students has been clear about the importance of participation in the Erasmus+ programme and the need to maintain the quality of faculty.
7. The Welsh Government is working with the student voice, the sector, and the institutions to ensure a consistent message about the importance of providing security and stability for EU staff and students.
8. The Welsh Government is also working to attract postgraduate work and postgraduate students into the system, and to address the issue of post-study work visas.

1. * The group is discussing the use of the Pupil Development Grant (PDG) in Wales to improve educational outcomes for disadvantaged pupils.
2. * The Cabinet Secretary for Education, Kirsty Williams, is present to answer questions about the PDG and its impact on schools.
3. * The group is concerned about the targeting of the PDG and whether it is being used appropriately to support pupils who are eligible for free school meals.
4. * The Cabinet Secretary emphasizes that individual interventions should only be targeted at pupils who are eligible for free school meals, but schools may use PDG funding for universal interventions if they can demonstrate a disproportionate effect on the outcomes of pupils on free school meals.
5. * The Cabinet Secretary acknowledges that the PDG should be used to support more able and talented pupils who are eligible for free school meals, and provides examples of good practice in this area.
6. * The group discusses the eligibility criteria for the PDG and whether free school meals is the best measure of identifying which pupils to target. The Cabinet Secretary suggests that it is the best available measure, but acknowledges that it may not be perfect.
7. * The group also discusses the flexibility of the PDG and whether it is being used in a consistent way across schools and regions. The Cabinet Secretary suggests that new PDG regional advisers will help to ensure more consistent practice.

3. The Cabinet Secretary emphasized the importance of PDG in supporting more able and talented children, and provided examples of good practice in this area.
