7. The Cabinet Secretary stated that the majority of schools are making well thought out and appropriate decisions on how to use PDG, but Estyn reported that only two thirds of primary and secondary schools make effective use of the PDG. The Cabinet Secretary emphasized the importance of leadership in the effective use of PDG.

* The discussion is about the final evidence session for the inquiry into targeted funding to improve educational outcomes.
 * Kirsty Williams AM, Cabinet Secretary for Education; Steve Davies, director of the education directorate; and Ruth Conway, deputy director, support for learners division are present to answer questions.
 * The discussion focuses on the Pupil Development Grant (PDG) and its use to support children eligible for free school meals.
 * There is a concern that the PDG is being used more widely than just those eligible for free school meals and that it is predominantly focused on low-attaining pupils who are eligible for free school meals.
 * The Cabinet Secretary emphasizes that individual interventions should only be targeted at those children who are eligible for free school meals, but schools may use PDG funding for universal interventions if they can demonstrate that it has a disproportionate effect on the outcomes for children on free school meals.
 * The Cabinet Secretary also mentions the use of PDG for more able and talented children and gives an example of a 'window on the world' bus in Pembrokeshire, which is used to raise aspirations and give children who are more able and talented, who are eligible for PDG, those experiences.
 * The Cabinet Secretary acknowledges that there is a need for greater awareness of how the PDG should be used at the coalface and that consortia and others need to have measures in place to demonstrate that it is being used properly.
 * The Cabinet Secretary mentions that eligibility for free school meals is the best measure of identifying which pupils to target, but she is open to discussions with local government about different ways to identify relative need.
 * The Cabinet Secretary also mentions that there is flexibility in the system regarding the once-a-year eligibility for free school meals and that issues around flexibility are actively being considered.

1. Dr Frank Atherton, the Chief Medical Officer for Wales, and Nathan Cook, head of the healthy and active branch at Welsh Government, discussed the draft strategy 'Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales' with the Children, Young People and Education Committee.
2. Dr Atherton expressed confidence that the strategy will deliver for children and young people, and discussed the engagement they have had with children and young people to inform the draft strategy.
3. The discussion also covered leadership, investment, and partnership working in implementing the plan. Dr Atherton emphasized the importance of a whole-system approach and local ownership and leadership.
4. The committee also discussed the child measurement programme, the planning system, and community sport infrastructure in relation to the strategy. Dr Atherton expressed support for the use of health impact assessments to inform policy decisions.

• The Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales draft strategy is being scrutinized by the Children, Young People and Education Committee.
• Dr Frank Atherton, the Chief Medical Officer for Wales, and Nathan Cook, head of the healthy and active branch at Welsh Government, are present to answer questions.
• Dr Atherton is confident that the strategy will deliver for children and young people, and the consultation has included engagement with children and young people in various forums.
• Dr Atherton advises that a target for reducing obesity among children may be considered, but it needs to balance deliverability with challenge.
• The level of investment needed to implement the plan has not been quantified yet, but it will depend on the actions that come out of the consultation and the effectiveness of existing programs.
• The revenue produced by the levy on soft drinks could be used towards efforts to reduce childhood obesity, but Dr Atherton is not in favor of hypothecation.
• The national implementation board that will lead the delivery of the plan will be accountable to Ministers, and it is important to have leadership and governance to coordinate action and drive change across relevant partners.
• The child measurement programme is the main source of data on childhood obesity, and a second measurement taking place in Wales is being considered to better understand the point at which children start to become overweight.

The strategy will be informed by a consultation, which includes questions on the use of the planning system to restrict hot food takeaways around schools, the potential for legislation to restrict price promotions and ban energy drinks, and the use of health impact assessments to inform policy decisions.

1. The speakers are discussing a meeting about speech recognition technology, where the competitors realized they were not friends but rivals.
2. They discussed issues with voice activity detectors and how it affected the recognition of clean speech.
3. The group agreed to do a new evaluation without voice activity detectors, but there was disagreement on the algorithm used.
4. French Telecom claimed that people would steal their techniques, but the group argued that it would be obvious if someone copied their code.
5. The group also discussed the weights assigned to different systems and how they could manipulate the numbers.
6. The speakers mentioned that they were working on noise separation and trying to provide a better initial estimate of the mel spectrum.
7. They also discussed TRAP recognition, which involves recognizing speech based on a shortened spectrum and taking the time trajectory of the energy at a given frequency.
8. The group talked about the critical band spectrum and how they could get an advantage by using two critical bands at the same time.
9. They also discussed how to convert energy over time in a particular frequency band into a vector of numbers.
10. The speakers mentioned that they were trying to understand what the vector actually represents and how correlated the elements of the vector are.

1. Dr. David Blaney, the Chief Executive of the Higher Education Funding Council for Wales, was invited to give evidence on the impact of Brexit on higher and further education in Wales.
2. Dr. Blaney discussed the exposure of the Welsh higher education sector to EU-sourced income, including EU students, structural funds, and EU research funding. He also mentioned signs of decreased applications from EU students and increasing difficulties in playing in EU collaborative research activities.
3. The main pressures on the Welsh higher education sector include the funding position, student recruitment, pay and pension costs, increased student expectations for modern facilities, and uncertainty about potential consequences from the review of fees and funding in England.

* The text is a transcript of a meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee discussing the impact of Brexit on higher and further education in Wales.
  * The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales (HEFCW) is giving evidence on the matter, represented by Dr David Blaney, Chief Executive, and Bethan Owen, Director of Institutional Engagement.
  * HEFCW has identified some impact of Brexit on Welsh higher education, including a decrease in applications from EU students and potential difficulties in collaborative research activities with EU partners.
  * The financial impact of Brexit on Welsh higher education is uncertain, but HEFCW is monitoring the situation and working with the Welsh Government to mitigate any negative effects.
  * The main pressures on the Welsh higher education sector include funding, student recruitment, pay and pension costs, infrastructure needs, and uncertainty about potential changes to fees and funding in England.
  * The decrease in EU student applications to Welsh universities is due to a combination of factors, including changes in student support arrangements and perceptions of safety and investment in facilities.
  * HEFCW is working with the sector to promote Wales as a good place to study and differentiate it from other parts of the UK.
  * The Welsh Government is expected to release additional funding to the higher education sector as part of the Diamond review recommendations, but the timing and amount are uncertain.
  * The committee also discusses other papers, including a letter from the Cabinet Secretary for Education on the school organization code and a letter from the Minister for Children, Older People and Social Care on the Childcare Funding (Wales) Bill.

1. The Children, Young People and Education Committee held a meeting to discuss the Welsh baccalaureate qualification with Kirsty Williams AM, Cabinet Secretary for Education; Kevin Palmer, deputy director, pedagogy, leadership and professional learning; and Andrew Clark, deputy director, further education and apprenticeships division.
2. The Cabinet Secretary values the qualification and believes it helps ensure a broad and balanced curriculum, preparing students for further study and the world of work.
3. The Welsh baccalaureate is generally valued by learners and teachers, but there have been concerns raised about workload, balancing it with other qualifications, and its impact on well-being.
4. The Cabinet Secretary believes that the qualification should be the norm for students, but flexibility is needed to ensure the well-being of individual students.
5. The value of the Welsh baccalaureate is not consistently understood by employers, and the Government is working with Qualifications Wales to develop a joint communication plan to address this issue.
6. Consistency in the delivery of the Welsh baccalaureate is a concern, and the Cabinet Secretary is looking to ensure more consistency through professional learning, teacher training, and performance measures.
7. There have been mixed opinions about the rigor of the qualification, with some stakeholders claiming it lacks rigor and has inflated grades. The Cabinet Secretary maintains that the qualification is rigorous and equivalent to an A-level.
8. There is inconsistency in how universities value the Welsh baccalaureate, with some not accepting it as equivalent to an A-level. The Cabinet Secretary has been working with universities to ensure they understand the value of the qualification.
9. Teachers have expressed concerns about spoon-feeding and passive marking in the qualification, but the Cabinet Secretary believes that the individual project element of the Welsh baccalaureate is difficult to game.
10. The Cabinet Secretary is confident that the university sector values the Welsh baccalaureate and that it does not disadvantage Welsh students. However, the committee has received evidence suggesting inconsistency in how universities use the Welsh bac as a tool for application.

She also mentioned that the Bill is not intended to create a new offence, but to remove a defense to an offence of common assault.

3. <summary>The team discussed the importance of the look and feel of the remote, as well as its technological innovation and ease of use in the market.</summary>
4. <summary>The team also talked about the trend of using bright, natural colors in fashion and technology for the next year, and they plan to incorporate this into the design.</summary>
5. <summary>The team decided to use kinetic energy as an additional feature, allowing the remote to be charged by squeezing it.</summary>
6. <summary>The team will work together to create a physical prototype of the remote for the next meeting.</summary>
7. <summary>The team will also receive a profit-sharing incentive for the success of the product.</summary>

1. The team is tasked to create a new, original, trendy, and user-friendly remote control for television.
2. The team discussed the design aspects, roles, and functions of the remote control.
3. There are three kinds of designs: functional design, conceptual design, and detail design.
4. The functional design is assigned to the industrial designer, user interface to Norman, and marketing to the marketing team.
5. The remote control should have a speech recognition interface for easy channel selection.
6. The remote control should have a small size, and the speech recognition system could be integrated into the TV itself.
7. The remote control should have a function to choose content instead of channels.
8. The team will gather information on how to get the content and discuss it in the next meeting.

1. The project aims to create a new remote control that is original, trendy, and user-friendly.
2. The team will be divided into three parts: functional design, conceptual design, and detailed design.
3. Each team member will work on their own ideas and then collaborate with the rest of the team.
4. The team members introduced themselves and drew their favorite animals, explaining their favorite characteristics.
5. The remote control should be produced at a maximum cost of 1250 Euro to make a profit of 15 million Euro from sales.
6. The team discussed their experiences using remote controls and their ideas for creating a new one.
7. There was a conflict over combining all remotes into one versus having multiple remotes.
8. The team discussed the idea of having one remote with major functions and another with special functions.
9. The team will design a remote control for a television only and will consider the size of the buttons for older people or those with poor hand-eye coordination.
10. The next meeting will cover individual actions and contributions, and the project manager will send out minutes and slides from the meeting.

1. The group discussed the presentation of the prototype for a remote control designed to look like a banana.
2. Decisions from the last meeting were reviewed, including no LCD, no speech recognition technology, a banana look and feel, use of wheels and buttons, and a base station for battery charging and remote calling.
3. The industrial designer presented the final design, including a banana-shaped remote with scroll wheels for volume and channel control, a turbo button for quick channel scrolling, and a banana-shaped base station with a button for calling the remote.
4. The group discussed the use of solar cells and rechargeable batteries for the remote, with the final decision being to use only rechargeable batteries.
5. The group evaluated the remote's design using a list of criteria, giving it high marks for being fancy and handy, but lower marks for functionality due to its limited use as a T\_V\_ remote.
6. The group discussed the potential market for the remote, with some expressing skepticism about its appeal to anyone outside of young trendsetters.
7. The group estimated the production costs of the remote, finding that it was currently over budget but could be adjusted by using plastic instead of rubber and simplifying the interface.
8. The group discussed the potential for expanding the remote's capabilities to control other devices and create a version two with additional features.
9. The group discussed the possibility of creating a real prototype for further evaluation and use in homes.

• The group discussed the design of a remote control in the shape of a banana, including its base station, scroll wheels, turbo button, and teletext functionality.
• The group evaluated the design using a list of criteria, assigning scores from 1 to 7 for factors such as fancy, handy, functional, cool features, easy to use, and price.
• The group discussed the need for further evaluation with the target market and potential simplification of the design, as well as the possibility of expanding the remote's functionality to control other devices and mood lighting.

1. The team discussed the final design of the remote control, which includes a banana-shaped design with a base station that has a banana leaf look and feel. The remote has two scroll wheels for volume and channel control, and a turbo button for quickly scrolling through channels.
2. The team discussed the use of the turbo button as an on/off switch and a teletext button. They also discussed the use of solar cells and rechargeable batteries for power, and the weight and color options of the remote.
3. The team evaluated the design based on a list of criteria, such as whether it is fancy, handy, functional, cool, and easy to use. They also discussed the potential market for the remote and the target price.
4. The team discussed the production costs of the remote and determined that they need to be below 12.5 Euros. They went through the list of components and materials needed for the remote and the base station, and made adjustments to stay within budget.
5. The team discussed the need for further evaluation of the design with the target market and the possibility of simplifying the design and expanding its functionality to control other devices and mood lighting. They also discussed the possibility of making a real prototype for further evaluation.

1. The Welsh Government discussed the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales during a virtual meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee.
2. The meeting was held in accordance with Standing Orders to protect public health and was broadcast live on Senedd.tv.
3. Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, Steve Davies, director of the education directorate, and Huw Morris, group director, skills, higher education and lifelong learning, attended the meeting.
4. The Minister expressed gratitude to school staff, key workers, and parents for their efforts during the pandemic.
5. The Minister outlined five principles for reopening schools, including considering the safety and well-being of children, young people, and staff, and building confidence for parents and professionals.
6. The Minister also discussed the challenges facing the education system, including the need to tackle social distancing and school transport issues.
7. The Minister confirmed that schools will not be returning to normal imminently and that a return to normal is not imminent.
8. The Minister also discussed the importance of testing, tracing, and quarantine in the next phase of the Government's response to the pandemic.

• Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, Steve Davies, director of the education directorate, and Huw Morris, group director, skills, higher education and lifelong learning, attended a virtual meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee to discuss the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales.
• The Minister stated that her primary concern is the health and well-being of children, young people, and staff in education settings. She expressed gratitude to school staff for their efforts in keeping schools open for vulnerable children and the children of key workers.
• The Minister outlined five principles that will guide her decision on when schools might reopen, including considering the safety and well-being of children, young people, and staff, taking a wider view of the Welsh Government's response to the pandemic, communicating clearly with parents and staff, making decisions based on evidence, and considering which groups of children should return to school first and how to operationalize that.
• The Minister stated that schools will not return to normal imminently and that a return to normal is not imminent. She also mentioned that the principles apply to both schools and further education colleges, and that the Welsh Government is working with representatives of the higher education sector to include them in the work.
• The Minister provided data on the number of schools open, the number of children attending, and the number of staff involved, and stated that 85% of the children attending are vulnerable children. She also mentioned that 15 teachers have been tested for COVID-19, and two of those results have come back as positive.

• The Welsh Government discussed the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales during a virtual meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee.
• Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, Steve Davies, director of the education directorate, and Huw Morris, group director, skills, higher education and lifelong learning, attended the meeting and answered questions from the committee.
• The Minister stated that her primary concern is the health and well-being of children, young people, and staff in education settings. She also expressed gratitude to school staff, parents, and carers for their efforts during the pandemic.
• The Minister outlined five principles that will guide her decision on when schools will reopen, including considering the safety and well-being of children and staff, taking a four-nation approach, and communicating clearly with parents and staff.
• The Minister also discussed the challenges facing the education system, including the need to ensure social distancing, provide adequate workforce, and address transportation issues. She emphasized that a return to normal is not imminent.

• Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, Steve Davies, director of the education directorate, and Huw Morris, group director, skills, higher education and lifelong learning, attended a virtual meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee to discuss the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales.
• The Minister expressed gratitude to school staff, key workers, and parents for their efforts in keeping schools open and supporting children's learning at home during the pandemic.
• Hefin David AM asked about the principles for reopening schools, to which the Minister replied that it would be done gradually and based on the advice of medical and scientific advisers, taking into account the safety and well-being of children, young people, and staff.
• Sian Gwenllian AM raised concerns about the mixed message conveyed by discussing reopening schools when testing for COVID-19 has not been sufficiently developed. The Minister clarified that they are not relaxing any restrictions and that schools will only reopen when it is safe to do so.
• Dawn Bowden AM asked about the arrangements for vulnerable children attending school hubs, to which the Minister replied that they are working with local authorities and social services to ensure that children and young people with a social worker have been risk assessed and are receiving support.
• The Minister also mentioned that they are working with the higher education sector to share thinking on the challenges facing further education and universities, although the principles do not explicitly apply to them.
• The Minister provided data on the number of schools open and the number of children and staff attending, with 85% of the children being vulnerable or the children of key workers. She also mentioned that 15 teachers have been tested for COVID-19, with 2 testing positive.

1. <summary>The Welsh Government discussed the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales during a virtual meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee.</summary>
2. <summary>Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, outlined five principles for reopening schools, including considering the safety and well-being of children, young people, and staff, clear communication, and addressing practical issues such as social distancing and school transport.</summary>
3. <summary>The Minister also discussed the current situation of school hubs, which are open for the children of key workers and vulnerable children, with 5.6% of the teaching population working in those hubs and 85% of the children attending being children of key workers.</summary>
4. <summary>The Minister also mentioned the importance of testing in the next phase of the Government's response to the pandemic and that the ability to test, trace, and quarantine will be crucial in all aspects of the Government's work to respond to this pandemic.</summary>

1. The Welsh Government is working on a four-nation basis to address the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic to education in Wales.
2. The Minister for Education, Kirsty Williams AM, has set out five principles to guide the decision-making process for reopening schools, which will be based on the advice of medical and scientific advisers.
3. The reopening of schools will not be imminent and will depend on the safety and well-being of children, young people, and staff.
4. The Minister has published the principles to build confidence for parents and professionals and to give them time to plan for any changes.
5. The Minister has also emphasized the importance of considering the needs of vulnerable children and those with additional learning needs in the decision-making process.
6. The Welsh Government is working with representatives of the higher education sector to include them in the planning process and to ensure that they are kept informed of any developments.
7. The number of schools that are open and the number of children and staff attending those schools is being published by the Welsh Government.
8. The Welsh Government is working to ensure the safety of staff and children in schools that are currently open and is monitoring the number of staff who have been tested for COVID-19.
9. The Welsh Government is providing additional funding to local authorities to increase and ramp up services to support children and families with their mental health and well-being during this time.
10. The Welsh Government is providing guidance to parents on how they can support their children's learning during this time and is working to ensure that all children have access to the hardware and connectivity they need to participate in digital learning.

1. The Welsh Government discussed the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales during a virtual meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee.
2. Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, outlined the primary concern being the health and well-being of children, young people, and staff in education settings. She also mentioned the efforts of school communities in keeping schools open for vulnerable children and children of key workers.
3. The Minister also discussed the principles that will guide the decision to reopen schools, including considering the safety and well-being of children, young people, and staff, clear communication of decisions, identifying appropriate groups for accessing education within a school setting, and operationalizing safe settings with adequate workforce and addressing social distancing, transportation, and gathering issues.

1. The Welsh Government has made the decision to close all schools in Wales due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
2. From next week, schools will have a new purpose, including supporting vulnerable children and ensuring continuity of learning.
3. All maintained schools in Wales already have access to a range of digital tools to support distance learning.
4. The decision to cancel summer exams has been made, with students being awarded a fair grade based on available information.
5. The Government is working to ensure the continuity of free school meals for eligible students during the school closures.
6. The Government is also working to ensure the continuity of funding for early years and childcare settings.
7. The Government is considering the needs of vulnerable children, including those with additional learning needs and those at risk of domestic abuse.
8. The Government is working to ensure the safety and well-being of all children and staff in educational settings during the pandemic.

1. The Welsh Government is working to ensure the continuity of education during the COVID-19 pandemic, while prioritizing public health.
2. Schools will have a new purpose from next week, including supporting those most in need and ensuring continuity of learning.
3. All maintained schools in Wales have access to digital tools for distance learning through the Hwb platform.
4. The decision to cancel summer exams was made to ensure fairness and minimize disruption for learners.
5. Schools are being asked to prioritize providing safe and secure places for children of key workers and those in need of free school meals.
6. The government is working with local authorities to develop plans to support vulnerable children and those with additional learning needs.
7. The government is considering the needs of specific groups such as young carers and children at risk of domestic abuse.
8. The government is working to ensure continuity of funding for early years and childcare settings, including Cylch Meithrin.
9. The government is providing clarity on the expectations for schools next week and will communicate these to schools today.
10. The government is having ongoing discussions with universities and FE colleges about their response to the pandemic.

* The text is a transcript of a meeting between the Children, Young People and Education Committee and the Welsh Government to discuss the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on education in Wales.
  * The meeting was attended by Kirsty Williams, the Minister for Education; Steve Davies, director of the education directorate; Huw Morris, group director, skills, higher education and lifelong learning; and Rob Orford, chief scientific adviser for health.
  * The Minister for Education made an opening statement about the Welsh Government's response to the pandemic and the measures taken to ensure the safety of staff and pupils in educational settings.
  * The committee members asked questions about the new purpose of schools, the provision for vulnerable children and those with additional learning needs, and the communication strategy for parents.
  * The Minister for Education also discussed the cancellation of exams and the plan to award grades to students based on a range of information.
  * The committee members also asked questions about the impact of the pandemic on colleges and universities, and the support for students and staff.
  * The Minister for Education assured the committee that student maintenance payments will continue as normal and that discussions are ongoing with the Student Loans Company.
  * The committee members also asked about the support for the mental health and well-being of staff and learners during the pandemic.
  * The meeting ended with a motion to exclude the public for the remainder of the meeting.

1. The Welsh Government has closed all schools and is working to support vulnerable learners and ensure continuity of learning.
2. The new purpose of schools is to support those most in need, including people involved in the immediate response to the coronavirus outbreak, and to safeguard and continue the education of vulnerable and disadvantaged students.
3. All maintained schools in Wales have access to a range of digital tools through the Hwb digital learning platform, which includes virtual classrooms and video-conferencing facilities.
4. The Welsh Government has cancelled the summer exam series for GCSE, AS, and A-level students and will award grades based on a range of information.
5. The Welsh Government is working with local authorities and partners to develop plans to support vulnerable children, including those on the at-risk register and young carers.
6. The Welsh Government is considering the needs of children with additional learning needs and will work with local authorities to identify those children who may be in need.
7. The Welsh Government is communicating with parents and schools through various platforms, including a frequently asked education questions page on the Welsh Government website.
8. The Welsh Government is working with local authorities and schools to ensure the safety and well-being of students and staff during the coronavirus pandemic.

1. The Welsh Government has decided to close all schools from a certain date due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
2. The priority now is to operationalize a practical response to support those most in need, including front-line response workers and vulnerable children.
3. Schools will have a new purpose of supporting and safeguarding the vulnerable and ensuring continuity of learning.
4. All maintained schools in Wales already have access to a range of digital tools for distance learning, and a guide on how to use them has been developed.
5. The decision to cancel the summer exam series was made to give early certainty to students and staff, and learners will be awarded a fair grade based on available information.
6. The Government is working to ensure that children who receive free school meals will continue to do so, even if schools are closed.
7. The Government is also working to ensure that the needs of children with additional learning needs are met during this time.
8. The Government is considering the needs of vulnerable children, including those who are young carers or at risk of witnessing domestic abuse, and will work with schools to ensure that these children are included in the provision for vulnerable children.

1. The Welsh Government held a meeting regarding the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on education in Wales. The meeting was attended by Kirsty Williams, Minister for Education; Steve Davies, director of the education directorate; Huw Morris, group director, skills, higher education and lifelong learning; and Rob Orford, chief scientific adviser for health.
2. The Minister announced that schools will be closed from March 23rd for statutory education provision, but will reopen to support those most in need, including people involved in the immediate response to the coronavirus outbreak. The Minister also announced that the summer exam series will not proceed, and learners due to sit these exams will be awarded a fair grade to recognize their work.
3. The Minister and officials discussed the new purpose of schools, which includes supporting and safeguarding the vulnerable and ensuring continuity of learning. They also discussed the importance of ensuring the well-being of staff and learners during this time.
4. The Minister and officials answered questions from Members regarding the new purpose of schools, the cancellation of exams, and the impact on vulnerable learners. They also discussed the potential impact of emergency legislation on education in Wales.

1. The group discussed the unintended consequences of the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill during a scrutiny session.
2. Witnesses including Sally Jenkins, Alastair Birch, and Huw David attended the session and expressed their support for the Bill, citing the need to uphold the rights of the child and promote well-being.
3. The witnesses also discussed the potential impact of the Bill on social services, education, and other services, as well as the importance of awareness raising and training for professionals.
4. The group also discussed the need for resources to implement the Bill effectively and ensure that vulnerable families in Wales are not negatively impacted.

1. The witnesses, including Sally Jenkins from the Association of Directors of Social Services, Alastair Birch from the Association of Directors of Education Wales, and Huw David from the Welsh Local Government Association, expressed their support for the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill.
2. They believe that the current law is ineffective and unclear, and that the rights of the child should be upheld. They also mentioned the importance of the voice of the child and the need for clarity in the definition of corporal punishment.
3. The witnesses discussed the potential impact of the Bill on their respective services, including the need for awareness raising and training for educational professionals, and the importance of simplicity in the Bill.
4. They also mentioned the need for resources for the implementation of the Bill and the importance of involving families, carers, and parents in the process.

1. The witnesses support the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill, which aims to remove the defence of reasonable punishment from Welsh law and clarify the definition of corporal punishment.
2. The witnesses believe that the current law is ineffective and unclear, and that it undermines child protection and fails to protect children from harm.
3. The witnesses emphasize the need for greater clarity around the definition of corporal punishment, but acknowledge that it is not essential to be on the face of the Bill.
4. The witnesses are confident that the Bill can be implemented without major impact on their capacity to deal with it, but acknowledge the need for further work to determine the cost implications for all agencies involved.
5. The witnesses highlight the importance of awareness raising and training for professionals in education, social services, and other relevant agencies to support the implementation of the Bill.
6. The witnesses stress that the Bill is not intended to criminalize parents, but to clarify the rights of children and improve their well-being.
7. The witnesses call for full involvement and commitment from Welsh Government in the implementation phase, including a major awareness-raising campaign and support for parents and carers.

1. The witnesses, representing the Association of Directors of Social Services, the Association of Directors of Education Wales, and the Welsh Local Government Association, expressed their support for the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill during a scrutiny session of the Children, Young People and Education Committee.
2. The witnesses emphasized the importance of raising awareness about the Bill and clarifying the definition of corporal punishment, and discussed the potential impact of the Bill on their respective organizations and services. They also highlighted the need for adequate resources and support to ensure successful implementation of the Bill.

• The witnesses, including Sally Jenkins, Alastair Birch, and Huw David, expressed their support for the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill, emphasizing the importance of upholding the rights of the child and clarifying the current ambiguity in the law.

• The witnesses also discussed the potential impact of the Bill on their respective areas, including social services, education, and local government. They acknowledged the need for awareness-raising, training, and resources to ensure successful implementation of the Bill, while also addressing concerns about unintended consequences and the potential for increased referrals to social services.

1. The Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill had its sixth scrutiny session, with witnesses from the Association of Directors of Social Services (ADSS), Association of Directors of Education Wales (ADEW), and the Welsh Local Government Association (WLGA).
2. The witnesses expressed their support for the Bill, stating that the current law is ineffective and unclear in protecting the rights of the child, which should be upheld according to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child.
3. The witnesses also mentioned that the Bill would bring clarity to professionals, children, and parents, and would help in creating a safer environment for children in schools and colleges.
4. The witnesses were asked about the evidence provided by social services regarding the harm caused by physical punishment, to which they responded that children find physical punishment demeaning and emotionally damaging, and that it is part of a continuum that perpetuates violence against children.
5. The witnesses were also asked about the need for greater clarity around the definition of corporal punishment, to which they responded that it is not essential for it to be on the face of the Bill, but rather during the implementation phase.
6. The witnesses emphasized the importance of awareness raising and the need for full involvement of families, carers, and parents in the implementation of the Bill, as well as the need for a universal offer of support services for parents who struggle with parenting.

1. The meeting is a discussion of a prototype for a new remote control design.
2. The prototype is a handheld device with a curved design, large push buttons, and an infrared feature to control a television.

4. The remote control is designed to be simple and easy to use, with a focus on the button arrangement that resembles a compass point.
5. The group also discusses the potential for the remote control to be shaped like a banana.
6. The group evaluates the prototype based on user requirements and hot trends, considering factors such as price, aesthetic, technology, and ease of use.
7. The group determines that the prototype is easy to use, attractive, and cost-saving, but not particularly innovative or technologically advanced.
8. The group also discusses the potential for the remote control to use kinetic energy.
9. The group determines that the prototype meets the project requirements and is within budget.

1. The group is discussing the transcription of audio recordings and the challenges of identifying and marking breaths in the transcripts.
2. There is a desire to balance the level of detail in the transcripts with the effort required to create them, as marking every breath may be too time-consuming for the transcribers.
3. There is also a need to consider the use cases for the transcripts, as some applications may require more detailed annotations than others.
4. The group is considering the use of automatic breath detection to help reduce the workload on the transcribers.
5. There is also discussion of using time boundaries to mark off words from non-words, which could be a more efficient way of indicating the presence of breaths and other non-verbal sounds.
6. The group plans to seek input from Liz and Andreas, who have experience with transcribing breaths in their own work.

1. The group discussed the final design of a remote control, including its look-and-feel, usability interface design, and product evaluation. They also discussed the finance and budget control, and found that producing the remote for the desired price of 12.5 Euros per remote would be challenging.
2. The group evaluated the design based on seven criteria: is the remote fancy, innovative, easy to use, functional, within budget, fitting the target group, and recognizable. The evaluation resulted in a score of 84% (41 out of 49).
3. The group discussed the project process and identified areas for improvement, including the timing of the finance information and the room for creativity. They also discussed leadership, teamwork, and means for the tasks.
4. The group discussed potential new ideas for having similar meetings, such as having each member put in their own score for evaluation criteria.
5. The group also discussed the possibility of marketing the remote to a wider audience, including younger people, by offering different front covers. They also discussed the potential popularity of the remote in the American market.

* The meeting is about discussing the results of a speech recognition experiment.
 
 * The results from ICSI OGI system were not as good as expected, possibly due to issues with the features obtained from OGI.
 
 * There is still some mystery regarding the Danish results, as the straight features did not yield the same results as the ICSI OGI system.
 
 * The team has some time to figure out the issues, until Saturday midnight.
 
 * The methods used in the experiment were able to reduce the error rate by a fourth to a half, depending on the case.
 
 * The team is considering combining the best ideas from other proposals while keeping resource usage in check.
 
 * The best system on the development set had a relative reduction in word error rate of about 54%, while the worst system had a reduction of 33%.
 
 * The two systems that performed best on the development set used spectral subtraction and a modification of cepstral parameters.
 
 * The team is also considering using models as an experiment and implementing filtering to reduce the bandwidth in the modulation spectrum, allowing for reduced transmission rates.

* The Welsh Government has asked the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) to review the progress of the Welsh education system against the national mission.
 * The OECD will publish their latest report on Welsh education on 23 March 2020, and the Welsh Government Minister for Education intends to make a statement to the Chamber on 24 March 2020.
 * The OECD review is part of the Welsh Government's ongoing development of self-evaluation, to ensure that they are constantly testing themselves and not just accepting their own orthodoxy.
 * The School Standards and Organisation (Wales) Act 2013 gives local authorities extensive powers of intervention in schools if they feel it is necessary.
 * The types of interventions that have been used include appointing additional governors to governing bodies, suspending a school's delegated budget, or applying to entirely replace a governing body and establish an intervention board.
 * The Welsh Government has not used these powers to date, but encourages local authorities to take a proactive approach to intervention and to use those powers.
 * The national evaluation and improvement resource is being developed to give continuity of approach right across Wales and to develop the skills within the system to have robust self-evaluation.
 * The resource is being tested and evaluated, with the intention of introducing it across the system at the start of the new academic year in September 2020.
 * The resource is being developed in co-construction with the OECD, middle tier and practitioners, to ensure that it is usable in schools.
 * The investment in school standards has been significant in this Assembly term, with 50% of the money going directly to supporting the professional learning of those who work with children.

3. The national evaluation and improvement resource is being developed to promote robust self-evaluation in schools and improve school standards. It is being tested and evaluated, with the aim of introducing it across the system in September 2020.

 • The School Standards and Organisation (Wales) Act 2013 gives local authorities extensive powers of intervention in schools. However, the use of these powers varies among local authorities.
